However m, we truly didn't enjoy the food.The beef tongue buns( or the beef tongue itself) was too salty, while the salad was mostly flavorless....The shrimps were way salty too. Pork belly tasted nice, only that it gets very oily. There were a couple bits that were just pure oily when you chew.........Most of the dish has peanuts so be aware.

Wow. Seriously so so so delicious. The food and service was top notch. We got the prix-fixe. I would highly recommend that if you want to try a variety of dishes. I can go on forever about how fresh and light everything was. The quality of ingredients was amazing, the flavors, the presentation -- everything was impressive! Felt like I was dining at a super expensive high-end restaurant for affordable prices. PLEASE get the tuna poke! It was probably the best poke I've ever had. A really good date spot especially if you want to impress your foodie date!

After a string of $$$ and $$$$ restaurants disappointing with bland food, finally there was Noreetuh to give hope. I was starting to fear that all these expensive restaurants were only able to charge so much based on their own hype. We started out with the Corned Beef Tongue Musubi which was very good.I had the Mochi-Crusted Black Bass which was cooked to perfection. It was just what I was looking for. My girlfriend had the Mentaiko Spaghetti, which was a bit too smokey for her, and even for me when I tasted it. The smokiness she said got better as she ate it more. Maybe her tastebuds just needed to adjust. She acknowledges that many people will really like how smokey it is, it was just a bit much for her tastes. So don't take this as a comment that you should avoid the dish because you may like it- many people on Yelp seem to. RESERVATION NOTE:They closed between lunch and dinner for a few hours, and don't have a ton of seating. Make a reservation for sure. *This a 4 Star rating simply because I like to reserve giving any place a 1 Star or 5 Star rating until I've been back a number of times.

Came here after the NYT review. It is amazing! Highly recommend. I sat at the bar and the general manager, Jin, was behind the bar and managing the table seating. He was extremely helpful a don extremely accommodating to all guests. The food was fabulous. The poke without saying, you need to try. The highlight however is the monkfish liver. So unique and so interesting. And so yummy. If you've never had this, then you MUST come here and try it. It has a flavor reminiscent of blue claw crab guacamole if you know what that is. The noodles are amazing as well. Definitely coming here again.

I just love Hawaiian food so it was off to check out Noreetuh in The East Village. I was introduced by the General Manager Jin who is super awesome giving me all sorts of recommendations and information about the menu. I started off with the kahlua croquettes which is Hawaiian pork mixed with mashed potatoes lightly fried, it was absolutely delicious. Then what I came for was the silken tofu with uni and salmon roe and mushroom. That dish was to die for. Supper yummy. And I finished with the musubi corn beef, which traditionally is made with spam, but they put a nice twist to it. That was phenomenal. I highly recommend Noreetuh to anyone who loves or wants to check out some of the best Hawaiian food in the city. Thanks Jin. Can't wait to come back for brunch

I have been to Noreetuh several times and tried almost everything in the menu. I have not been disappointed with any dishes. The team of Jin, Gerald & Co are extremely professional and friendly. I recommend Noreetuh for dinner with friends, anniversary, brunch.. basically everything occasion
Loved the brunch here! Definitely get the pickles, poke and loco moco.

Came here this weekend with my husband.  Wish I didn't waste a good Friday night out coming here.  My husband ordered the wine pairing and the waitress asked him for his preference of drinks.  The whole point of a pairing is for the wines to complement the dishes being served.  They kept refolding our paper napkins.  If you're going to go the refolding route, you should have cloth napkins.  The food was eh.  I didn't finish any of my dishes, and that is a rarity for me.  Each dish was bland and uninspired.  The only dish that was a savior was the poke.  The price isn't bad for a 3 course meal, I was just totally underwhelmed.

Ridiculous! Absolutely ridiculous food! My mind is blown, my tastebuds are tickled and I'm completely satisfied. The food is high quality, unique and perfectly prepared. The ambiance was elegant; service was on point and the timing of the courses was just right. We ate a lot and i mean a lot!! My favorites were the tofu with Uni, steak, Mochi waffles and the pineapple. It's a serious foodie place.

Came here for dinner with a few friends on Thursday and the food was delicious! Don't expect huge portions however each dish is so rich in flavor you wouldn't want a huge dish. My favorite dish was the Ice Cream Sundae dessert :) The shortbread cookies at the end were a nice treat.We ordered the Big Eyed Poke, Steak, Pork Belly, and Silken Tofu.The Silken Tofu dish is for those who can handle strong seafood flavor - tasted fresh!The Steak was buttery and the Pork Belly was so good! I loved the roasted veggies.

Yum!I met a friend here for dinner and we each decided to go for the prix-fixe so we could sample a variety from the menu for a decent price.For our appetizers (or "snacks" as they were listed on the menu) we got the silken tofu with uni & shiitake and the mochiko wings. The tofu was amazing and the texture was really lovely. The uni was kind of fishy, but neither of us are huge fans of uni so it's probably just our bias. The wings were awesome. The breading was really crispy and the sauce had a nice balance of sweet and savory.Our next course (the "starters") consisted of two different pokes: the big eye tuna poke and the octopus poke. The tuna was bright and fresh and not at all fishy. It had a sweet soy and sesame seasoning and the portion was quite generous. The octopus was lightly grilled until perfectly tender and it was served with baked beans, which was kind of odd but also worked nicely. The soft beans were a nice textural contrast with the octopus.For our mains, we shared the mentaiko spaghetti and the braised pork belly. The spaghetti was probably my favorite dish of the night. The pasta was cooked perfectly to al dente and had an unctuous fishy quality (in the best way possible). The pork belly was so tender it was just falling apart and was seasoned nicely.For dessert we shared the King's Hawaiian bread pudding. It was good but nothing to write home about. It's worth sharing for the experience.The staff were so smiley and the service was great. It's a bit pricey for sure, but you're paying for ambiance and the impeccable service so it's worth it for a special occasion, I'd say.

After reading about Chef Chung Chow and noreetuh in HAL's in-flight magazine, I knew I had to try to make it here. Brought a work group here for dinner and the food and service were spot on.My "food snob" colleagues called it their favorite meal in New York City on this trip and I wholeheartedly agree. Everyone was in love with their dishes from the poke, hearts of palm salad to the mentaiko spaghetti and Mochi-crusted bass. And the desserts....oh man! We were stuffed!Chef and partners Gerald and Jin are buddies from Per Se and sure know what they're doing. Love the island-inspired decor to the POG they serve -- Passion Orange Guava. Awesome! Chef is a Hawaii success story having grown up in a modest Honolulu neighborhood. Check out noreetuh...so much Aloha to be had here.

This restaurant serves up modern Hawaiian fare in  a hip setting with subtle Hawaiian theme through out the restaurant. It's amazing how many tables they can pack into this small space! There's a bar area with seating and tables  adjacent to it.  In the next room over is a narrow corridor of tables for 2 and 2  or three larger tables for larger parties.  You are literally able to rub elbows with another party when sitting in this room! Our waitress was very nice.  She was helpful without being too intrusive. The menu is divided into 4 main sections: Snacks, Starters , Main, and Dessert. There is a 3 course Prix Fixe Menu daily for Dinner for $42.  You actually can save some money doing so if you are going to order many dishes anyway.  The portions are smallish,  so you won't over do it.  My wife and I ordered 2 -  3 course prefix plus another app. We are such pigs! We ordered corned cow tongue musubi,  truffle taro chips,  mochico chicken wings,  grilled octopus,  big eye tuna poke,  mochi crusted black bass,  and pineapple braised black bass. If  we come back,  we would definitely get the taro chips,  tuna poke,  pineapple pork belly.  They were all a hit! The other dishes were good not great.  The cow tongue musubi was good but I don't think i enjoy the macadamia nut crunch texture in it,  and I couldn't taste the cilantro sauce.  The mochico chicken wings had a good crispy outside but the citrusy glaze made it too messy to eat.  I've been to Hawaii and mochico chicken usually is dry.  The flavor was good but I didn't taste the chili. We didn't even get any wings on this dish! The grilled octopus was ok but texture was chewy.  I tried my wife's black bass  was cooked perfect but was a little bland. I'm glad i tried Noreetuh,  but like another reviewer noted,  was not totally blown away but definitely a great place to have dinner and drinks. My wife and I enjoyed the dinner.  It's a nice atmosphere with a good wine and beer selection,  even sake.

Boyfriend and I really enjoyed our Noreetuh brunch!! The poke bowl was good enough but could have used more jalepenos. We loved the pork belly hash!! Next time we'd split that with extra eggs and extra toast. Great service, courteous and nice manager, too. Cute interior and good attention to little details. I liked the king Hawaiian bread but wish they had the rolls over sliced white bread. Pineapple brûlée was excellent to finish, big enough to share! With a touch of salt and lime juice/zest. Delicious!!

They sat us on a Saturday with 15minutes lead time on our reservation. Nice job, guys! Bathrooms had cool style. The rest of the place was pretty dark, but the layout was still legit. A little too noisy for my taste. Waiter was very courteous. Good wine selection. Some appetizers were a little too similar to each other but I enjoyed them nonetheless. The raw tuna appetizer was really fantastic and different.

Came here for brunch. Mochiko Fried chicken was very greasy and fatty. Waiter was friendly though. I admire the bold menu compared to other restaurants for brunch - Hawaiian Breakfast (spam), Hawaiian French Toast (caramelized pineapple, raisins), pork belly hash, etc. Roommate said they were alright.It's a very different brunch alternative from many restaurants. I do recommend to try. May come back.

I was here for brunch recently, and got the bruleed pineapple and pork belly hash to share with a friend, as well as a POG mimosa. Items in descending order: -The pineapple was amazing, and I noticed that a lot of other patrons ordered it, as well. I'd be surprised to learn it isn't among the top few menu options here. It's seriously so good: the contrast between soft fruit and crunchy brulee is to die for.-The POG mimosa was an interesting and very topical take on the classic orange juice mimosa. I wouldn't say it was terribly innovative, though, as far as the universe of possibilities for brunch beverages goes, so I'd call it middle of the road.-The pork belly hash was somewhat underwhelming, as I feel like they over-rendered the pork belly and thus made it more like crackling than I'd expected. Personally, I'd have preferred that they'd gone the other direction on the pork belly.Overall, a decent brunch with one very solid pick, one middle-of-the-road pick, and one pick that I probably wouldn't go back to on my next visit.

Dang. I kind of didn't need to want Hawaii more than I already do. It's kind of like finding out he reads books, or that he likes long walks on the beach. Did you really need *more* to entice you?We were enticed by the prix fixe. Everything was creative and possibly more "interesting" than traditional. The silken tofu was so curious, with the melding of arguably similar mushy? textures with vastly different tastes. The monkfish liver torchon was a powerful dish. Anything on a hawaiian roll is pretty addictive, so fair warning! I smeared some of the soy mayonnaise from the square tempura on this concoction, and my date thought that was weird but it was kind of interesting. I'm a big fan of trying different sauces on everything. Honestly, the winner of the night was the mentaiko spaghetti. Neither of us expected this at all, and we ordered it with some apprehension. But trust me, it completely stole the show. We probably would have fought over the single portion but we kept it pretty civil. This time.

I love Hawaiian food.  Not sure how this place missed the mark so badly for me because it seemed like a sure-fire hit.  Service was great, décor is borderline horrendous.  It's like a Japanese dojo meets TRON.  The truffle taro chips bar snack ($11) was the most overpriced/underwhelming bar snack I've had in New York City.  I just felt like I was being taken for a ride.I will give them bonus points for showcasing Hawaiian food.  But when in need of poke, I prefer Sons of Thunder.

Noreetuh has been on my radar for several months, and when I finally got to go, my excitement level was up to *here*. And perhaps that was its downfall - the hype built up my expectations and the food wasn't as mindblowing as I had hoped it'd be. It was good, surely, but not awesome.Crispy mushrooms - These were oyster mushrooms deep fried in crispy batter with a savory miso mayo dip. They were tasty, but you really couldn't have more than one or two because it was much too oily - oil wasn't hot enough, perhaps?Monkfish liver torchon - The monkfish liver suffered the same problem as the crispy mushroom. Tasty, fatty, and creamy, and I love the pairing of the pear and passionfruit, but there was a bit too much of it and I could have used less at a lower price.Sea urchin tagliatelle - I was torn between getting this and the mentaiko spaghetti, and I highly regretted my choice. I have a high tolerance for briny, fishy tastes (case in point: I eat sardines out a can and love ikura) but this was just way too fishy for me. There was something imbalanced about the dish - it could have used maybe a bit more richness or sweetness, but overall it just didn't cut it for me. At least they were generous with the sea urchin.Still, despite my expectations being not met, I would come back here and try the mentaiko spaghetti and hope that overturns my verdict. Service was great, and the manager Jin (twinsies!) showed gracious hospitality as well.

I highly recommend noreetuh for an exceptional dining experience. The ambience was simple yet sophisticated and the service was extremely attentive. Although many options on the menu looked delicious, my friend got the octopus to start and I had the tuna poke. Both were fresh and flavorful. We both had the uni tagliatelle which was particularly decadent. I was tempted by the Hawaiian king bread pudding, but we didn't want to spoil the meal by overdoing it. Great wine selection as well.

Not blown away, especially given the price point. Only a few dishes were truly great (the spaghetti; the squash tempura; the sausage). The fried mushrooms were flat out bad (all fry). Also, much darker lit than I imagined, given that it's a Hawaiian fusion joint. It is cute, cozy inside, and the service was very friendly. I enjoyed the wine pairing. But at the end of the night, my wallet was lighter yet my stomach wasn't full.

Incredible meal, best we've had this year for sure. Service was also impeccable. Truly inspired and well executed dishes. We had the big eye tuna, torchon and the grilled octopus- fabulous. Mochi crusted black bass was cooked to perfection, green beans and Chinese bacon were the perfect accompaniment. Staff was so welcoming and warm.

It's a cute and cozy fusion place, well decorated. Dishes are well plated. Everything I tried between my group of friends (hawaiian hearts of palm, fluke sashimi and mentaiko spaghetti) was fresh tasting and flavorful, but definitely not filling. It's not that kind of place to eat to be full I suppose. All the staff we encountered were pleasant and courteous. The bathroom was clean. Reservation is definitely recommended! I was also glad I had a HUGE lunch maybe 4 hours before hand otherwise I would need like 4 plates to get full maybe (if I had come in hungry haha). But I do eat a lot for anyone :P Overall, I would like to return one day and try more of their fresh tasting delights :)

Everything is delicious here! The ingredients are super fresh and cooked and seasoned to perfection! Uni is fresh and tastes perfect, I don't know why other reviewers don't like it.  You have to have a taste for it to enjoy the undertones of uni!  The service is amazing, the drink selection is amazing, the portions are quite large and the prix fixe is an amazing deal!!  I've tried the mentaiko spaghetti with butterfish and it was the most delicious dish I've ever had. The mochi crusted fluke is light and crispy at the same time and they do veggies amazing well (the night we went we had grilled romaine lettuce and delicious green beans with our entrees).  Don't forget to get dessert! That brûléed pineapple is mind blowingly simple and scrumptious! I'm coming back again and again!

Impressive wine list! Some unusual wine at really reasonable price! Jin is a real wine guy. Food is good as well (we like appetizers here more than entree). Grilled octopus and monkfish liver were delicious. :)
Amazing food! The Octopus was expertly made, and the Chocolate Haupia Sundae with Coconut Ice Cream and Graham crackers was absolutely incredible.

Everything was excellent..... service & food, all perfect!We had the poke, kobocha squash tempura, fluke sashimi, black bass, mentaiko spaghetti - all delicious!We'll be going back & definitely recommending it to friends.

The first time I passed by here, B and I were like what is this place? It was drawing a lot of crowd and we scoped out the menu and we were like oh, a Hawaiian place.I didn't really see anything here that drew me here, but I met A and A's from Hawaii and said this place is pretty good and K's friend is a partner here and said this place had really good food.I decided, why not give this place a try and so E and I came here and we shared the following items:crispy mushrooms with sweet miso - E wanted this, didn't see the appeal of thisblack angus steak with grilled romaine, sesame, red onion, taro - this was a bit on the bitter side for me for some reason and the meat was toughI got the sea urchin tagliatelle with spicy cod roe - I loveeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee uni, so of course I would love this and I asked the waiter where the uni comes from and he said California and I want to say this uni tasted like the first uni I have ever tasted in my entire life that made me swore off eating uni ever again. This uni was terrible, the fishiest uni ever and just didn't have the fresh buttery uni goodness that I found myself loving about this sea creature. I left all the uni's in the bowl and just ate the pasta. What a waste of money and not eating the best part, which I thought would have been the uni.E and I lives for bread pudding and I didn't even notice it on the menu, but we were a fan of the king's hawaiian bread pudding with rum raisins, pineapple ice cream. The texture was just a lot more mushy than what we are used to.I wouldn't go back here.....

Dined at Noreetuh last weekend and had a very tastebud-shaking experience. I was excited to try Hawaiian food, and while many of the dishes were quite good, not all of them worked for me. The awesome:Glazed pork bellyMonkfish liver with passion fruitButterfish spaghetti The just OK:Truffle taro chips King's Bread puddingThe not-so-awesome:Silken tofu with Uni The monkfish liver was probably my favorite dish of the night. The savory flavor and smooth texture of the liver worked perfectly with the sweet passion fruit. The pork belly was also delicious and cooked to perfection, and the spaghetti was a totally unexpected and delightful melding of flavors. You've never had spaghetti like this! The truffle taro chips and bread pudding were less special. The chips tasted like something you could get at Whole Foods, and the bread pudding was a bit too firm and luke warm for me. The pineapple ice cream it was served with was also cloyingly sweet. I struggled with the silken tofu. I know this is one of their most popular dishes, so perhaps it's just me, but I felt it was almost too fishy. The uni, which I typically enjoy, overpowered the dish, and the tofu was just a little too watery for my liking. The service was impeccable.Overall, I'm glad I tried a new cuisine and would definitely come back to experience more of the menu, but I didn't leave as satisfied as I'd hoped.

Amazing food and service! We tried the beef tongue (so tender), the silken tofu with uni (very light), tuna poke (grade A tuna quality), calamari poke (rich but not heavy), pork belly (so flavorful), sea bass (perfectly fried), and the chocolate sundae (perfection! chocolate panna cotta cubes with coconut ice cream, whipped cream, and graham crackers!). Excellent service - so attentive and considerate of allergies! Will definitely be going back!

This was the first stop of my east village food tour. I order the corned beef tongue musubi, big eye tuna poke and mochi-crusted bass from the prix fixe menu at $42 (plus $3 supp for the poke). The beef tongue was cooked perfectly, one piece was not enough! The musubi would've been better if they roasted the seaweed to give it some crisp. It, unfortunately, fell apart after a few bites. As a beef tongue lover, I would pass on this dish. I loved the variety of seaweeds in the poke. The tuna was fresh but was seasoned inconsistently. The few pieces that were well-seasoned was amazing. Overall the dish was refreshing but under seasoned to my tasting. I'm glad I chose the mochi-crusted bass as my entree, it was my favorite dish of the meal. The mochi crusting gave the fish extra crunch and crisp. Because the bass sat on top of sautéed string beans, the bottom crust of the fish became soggy and lost the crunchiness. The string beans were just as delicious as the fish. Sautéed in a vinegar sauce, it gave the string beans a perfect kick of acidity.

Food is overpriced and tasted below average.  I am from Hawaii, so I was looking forward to eating at this place and was thoroughly disappointed!!  Service was definitely missing the aloha spirit.  Will not be going there again.

Good Hawaiian food? In New York? Is that even possible?Well Noreetuh certainly gives it a great effort! I came here for brunch, and I realize that the dining experience can be totally different from dinner, but overall it seems like the quality of the service and food are very consistent!I got Pork belly hash; the pork was very crispy, almost...kind of hard. There were a few pieces that I really had to grind down; this was probably the only negative element of the dish. The eggs came very runny, which I love, and the toast was perfectly browned and had a nice sweetness to it. Pretty solid for $14! Funny enough, I came here with a Hawaiian friend, because I just had to get his opinion on the authenticity of the food! Overall, he seemed very satisfied with his Hawaiian breakfast, claiming that it was similar to what he made at home (I assume he meant ingredient-wise, probably not quality-wise).Noreetuh is a wonderful, slightly exotic option for either dinner or brunch! If you can make the trek all the way to 1st ave, I highly recommend this place.

I highly recommend the silken tofu.  I had this appetizer about 2 weeks ago and I'm still thinking about it!  I also had the big-eye tuna poke and pineapple braised pork belly, which was very good.  For desert I had the crispy mochi waffles.  The peanut better was good, but the waffles were very hard and tasted like plastic.  The staff was friendly and didn't rush us to leave, enough though the place was getting packed.

Super fun place. The food was delicious. We tried all the Hawaiian signature dishes; the masubi, poke, spam, kailua pork, uni, all of which was outstanding. My favorite was the uni pasta. They even had a neat ale called Kagua that is a Japanese beer brewed in Belgium, which was tasty and from what the waiter told me has only been in the states a couple of years.

Pretty good dining experience. Restaurant is kinda small so I would make reservations before coming. I haven't tried much Hawaiian food but I don't think this place is super authentic since there are pasta dishes. Spam musubi - 3/10 I was so excited to try this because the photos from other reviews looked good but it literally tasted like straight salt.Tuna poke - 6/10 this tasted okay, nothing memorable and wasn't worth the $18.Pineapple braised pork belly - 9/10 definitely try this dish, it was cooked so well and melted in my mouth. Sweet potatoes were a nice touch as well. Mochi waffles - 7/10 waffles were cooked well and peanut butter was yummy

We decided to try this restaurant after reading the write- up in New York magazine. The atmosphere Is sleek and modern. The restaurant is divided into two rooms. The service is attentive and helpful. The manager was chatting with us and told us of the BYOB option on Sunday nights. Wine  by the glass is about $15 so BYOB Is attractive. The fried squash was highly rated so we ordered  one each - this is a dish to share as it is a bit heavy. It almost tastes like yucca fries but a much more sophisticated preparation and presentation. You could also share the tuna poke - delicious chunks of tuna with macadamia nuts and chili peppers. My husband did the $42 prix fixe. He had the spam agnolotti with celery and truffles - excellent - about a dozen pieces. I had crispy sea bass with beans and Chinese bacon - a generous piece of flaky tender fish lightly fried on one side with a heaping portion of beans. We were too full for dessert. I saw the noodle entree at another table - enough to share. I would recommend sharing a few dishes to keep the bill reasonable and to have  the opportunity to taste some wonderful flavors.

Cuisine: 7Service: 8Decor: 7Value: 6Overall: 7Hawaiian food gone upscale with higher quality ingredients, fancier techniques, and sexier presentations. Our group of four shared everything and agreed almost 100% on all the dishes.  Most of the meal were hits, but there were a few major misses as well.  Here is a full breakdown.Truffle Taro Chips - 8/10.  Light, super crispy & delicious.  Truffle flavor is present but not overwhelming.Crispy Mushrooms - 7/10. Fried perfectly, but lacked a certain mushroom flavor.  Good but not a wow.Corn Beef Tongue Musubi - 9/10. Amazing flavors. Rice was great. Tongue was crazy tender. Cilantro sauce was harmonious. Seaweed could have been crispier.Silken Tofu - 7/10 Maine Uni was bitter and the miso was a bit overpowering. However, the tofu itself was sublime, along with the equally fantastic slightly slaty ikura.Monkfish Liver Torchon - 4/10 Passion Fruit overpowers the creamy liver.  Yet if you like desserts before your entree, you may enjoy this a lot.  The King bread was excellent.Big-Eye Tuna Poke - 7/10 The tuna itself was a bit bland, but the accompaniments were just right.  Though quite good, it is not of the quality of poke I had in Hawaii.Hawaiian Hearts of Palm - 5/10 Served in slices, but I prefer my hearts of palm whole in order to taste the tenderness when I bite into the center. Sauce was great, need more.Kalua Pig Croquettes - 9/10 Awesome!  You can really taste the tender and flavorful shredded pork among the creamy potato, nestled inside a crispy shell.Sea Urchin Tagliatelle 1/10 Honestly, I hate to rate anything (especially w/ uni) this low, but I had to on this dish.  Simply put, way too much parmesan.Pineapple Braised Pork Belly - 9/10 Holy crap! Talk about fork tender and absolutely yummy. Well, this is it. Not 10/10 because their wasn't much pineapple flavor.Garlic Shrimp Over Rice - 8/10 One of my favorite things in Hawaii to eat.  This super garlicky version is just as good as some of the best I had on the islands.Mentaiko Spaghetti - 8/10 First word to describe this pasta is smoky.  Spaghetti was a bit past al dente but still pretty good. The butterfish was yummy.Grilled Pineapple Brûlée - 10/10 Only problem with this dessert was that we all wanted more.  Sweet and salty.  Perfect.Adzuki Bean & Coconut Tapioca - 6/10 Great concept where the orange ice cream was just slight misplaced imo. I would have preferred a flavor with less zest.Crispy Mochi Waffle - 5/10 Sounds so cool, but lacked execution.  The mochi waffle was not crispy enough, though the whipped peanut butter was delicious.The decor was quite modern and the service was very good.  My glass was always full with water and our server had a smile every time he walked by.  There are still other interesting items on the menu I would like to try.  With a lack of good Hawaiian cuisine in NYC, I will be returning.

Came here for a friend's birthday dinner and had a great experience. The service was excellent and the food was inventive and tasty. We ordered a majority of items on the menu, but the standouts were the corned beef tongue musubi, kabocha squash tempura, big-eye tuna poke, chow noodles, mentaiko spaghetti, pineapple braised pork belly, and king's hawaiian bread pudding. Some dishes, such as the garlic shrimp over rice, were a bit basic, but still executed well. The portion sizes were perfect, but it was still a bit pricey in my opinion. However, I will definitely be back to try other menu items!

Casual restaurant that offers modern and elegant interpretations of Hawaiian food.The highlights: silken tofu w/ uni and ikura, squash tempura, mochi-crusted black bass. With respect to technique, everything is done very well. The flavors are balanced, and the portions are pretty much perfect for ordering the 3-course prix fixe. There were definitely some dishes which could have been done better. The hearts of palm salad was topped with blood oranges which clashed noticeably with the pecorino romano. The spam agnolotti, which I, as a spam lover, was excited for, ended up being rather bland, aside from the very generous amount of black truffles shaved on top of them. Still--where else will you get spam and truffle in the same dish? It's sort of the essence of what Noreetuh is about. Big shout out to the restaurant's staff: we agreed that the best part of the whole experience was the awesome, awesome service.

The service was awesome... Unfortunately the food wasn't. Over all I would describe both my husband and I's meals as mushy. The only good thing I had was the bread pudding at the end... Which wasn't even the best :( super disappointed, because I was really looking forward to eating here.

I went with a group of friends and the food was delicious. The only reason I gave it a 4 star instead of a 5 is because I went during Brunch and couldn't try some dishes because it was only part of their dinner menu. However, the brunch menu was very delicious but the portion in my opinion was on the smaller side. I would def recommend this place and will be going back to try their dinner menu.

I don't know anything about Hawaiian food. Other than the pizza, which doesn't even hail from the aloha state, Hawaiian cuisine isn't particularly pervasive in these parts. Attracted by several months of buzz, I finally made my way here! It's definitely an upscale take on the cuisine but I'll take any iteration I can.The sleek and minimalist decor along with the dim lighting and small-but-not-too-small space lends itself well to intimate gatherings of the romantic or platonic nature. Here with my boo, we were seated immediately thanks to reservations, and by the looks of it, I'd recommend making them.The menu quickly illustrated Hawaiian cuisine's interesting fusion of Polynesian and other various Asian cooking. For appetizers, we ordered the Silken Tofu and very popular Big-eye Tuna Poke. The tofu was topped with salmon roe, uni, and something sweet I couldn't identify. While I enjoyed the combined silky texture of everything and small bursts of flavor from the roe, the dish was a little too light on flavor. The tuna poke, on the other hand, was not. Slightly spicy, citrusy, and probably some other flavors I can't recall, the tuna mixed with seaweed and pickled jalapeños was so good. I loved how large the chunks of tuna were rather than being delicate slices too.For my main, I went with the mentaiko spaghetti with smoked butterfish. At first, I was worried it wasn't going to be enough food but the creamy fish roe sauce that coated the spaghetti did the trick. The entire dish was deliciously smoky and the heaping pile of aonori added a nice, if subtle, contrast to everything else. (Writing this while hungry was a bad idea.) My boyfriend ordered the pineapple glazed pork belly and the bite I had was really good. It was perfectly cooked and sweet without being too sweet. He loved it. After we ate our itty bitty complimentary shortbread cookies and paid the bill, we left more than satisfied with the food, service, and overall experience. Recommended!

Loved the food and service!  The prefix menu is a good deal with a variety.  We had the tempura and tuna poke and they were delicious.  The desserts were very unique.  We loved the mochi waffles!  So different and interesting yet very tasty. When in NYC, will definitely go back for more.

Unforgettable meal and pretty good value. Lucky enough to get a reservation at the last minute. Only per peeve was that our server - roger, was trying to rush us. That definitely dampened the experience for me. All the other servers and staff were very helpful and knowledgable.

First time having Hawaiian food and I was not disappointed. Sadly, or perhaps not, the impeccable service was the best part of the restaurant. Offering opinions, accommodating for reservation changes. Never without a drink. Superb!The mushroom and sweet potato snack starters were amazing. Such a nice entry to the meal. Next we ordered poke. I thought the dish was perfect. There were some pieces of tuna that were cut incorrectly which led to severe chewiness. But c'est la vie. The main course was...interesting to say the least. It was Hawaiian spaghetti apparently and I don't know maybe it just wasn't for me. It grew on me as I went on but the smoked fish just wasn't for me. I would return though!
Great meal. Great tasting menu with nice and clean flavors. Awesome service. Highly recommend for a nice adult evening out. Going back to try their regular dinner menu next time we're in town.

After just returning from Hawaii, my wife and I were looking for some great Hawaiian food in the city.  This place did not disappoint.  The food and service were wonderful and we will absolutely be coming back.

i went yesterday and had the 5 course  valentines menu for $75. it was pretty awesome and I usually hate tasting menus. I give the food a 5 but the no frills decor/bathroom/atmosphere of les a 3, so that gives them a 4. I would go back again.

Hawaiian cuisine is the original Asian fusion and this place takes it up a notch. They are creative with their flavors and ingredients which makes each dish a discovery of texture and taste. It's fun for the palate! We came on the last day of restaurant week and were able to sample many dishes that are available on the regular menu. We had crispy mushrooms (my fav!), tuna poke (flavors better than what we had in Hawaii though it's hard to beat the islands' freshness -we were just there!), taro chips (it's the truffles that make the dish), kobocha squash tempura (amazing w bonito flakes), pork belly  (so tender I could spread it on toast), octopus (cooked just right), and other dishes I didn't get to taste but the rest of my group really enjoyed. Ask Jin to do your wine pairings. He's truly knowledgeable. Service was excellent too. Wait staff was attentive - a class act for less than formal dining. I can't wait to try the Hawaiian brunch. If I'm going to eat spam, it's gonna be here.

OMG I cannot say enough about this place. Great great great service! They were quick and very friendly. The gentleman behind the bar gave us great recommendations on what to select from the restaurant week menu. Everything we ordered from appetizers to desserts were excellent. I would go back again and try other items on the menu. They definitely have unique interesting choices on the menu which was why we chose to dine at this place in the first place. It's a small place but it's worth eating at the bar of all the tables are taken. My friend and I couldn't stop talking about the food here. Recommendations: silken tofu,big-eye tuna poke, spam agnolotti, char-grilled octopus, king's hawaiian bread pudding, crispy mochi waffles

Came here for restaurant week because I was so excited to see a Hawaiian restaurant on the list! Loved it! Pricey...but loved it! Trendy ambiance, lovely wait staff and simple decor with paintings of the sea. Great vibes. Also, ample portions! I'm a big eater so it was perfect  started with the Tuna Poke (nicely seasoned and topped off with seaweed - so good and fresh), then had the mentaiko spaghetti (very flavorful, strong taste and unique. it had some sort of fish roe that gave it a powerful taste. Must get! Don't think I've ever tasted something like this before), and ended with the Haupia Sundae (great mixture of textures and flavors. A lovely end to the meal). All in all it was around $50+ per person, but I'll probably be back in the future for a special date night or celebratory dinner.

Came here with a group for a friend's birthday during Restaurant Week. First off, the host is wonderful and was extra attentive and considerate of all of the guests! Wine selection is very, very extensive. Try the Bruno Verdi Pinot Grigio ($45/bottle)!Here's a rundown of the food we tried - Appetizers: Silken Tofu w/Ikura & UniTuna PokeHearts of Palm SaladPretty big portions for each, like a fist sized amount of food. Mains:Pork BellyMentaiko SpaghettiVeggie Chow NoodlesAgain, big portions. I would also like to call out the chow noodles, they come with a ton of vegetables and are a great vegetarian option. Everyone really enjoyed their entreesDessert:Chocolate Haupia SundaeHawaiian Bread PuddingTapiocaThe raisins in the bread pudding are extra rummy. Like it is not cooked off and straight rum-soaked raisins. My favorite kind of raisins. Automatic five stars from me!!!!!!

Didn't live up to the hype. Even with the Restaurant Week prix fixe menu, the meal was a poor value.  Each course was delicious. Despite what other reviewers say, nothing was too salty or too acidic. Every flavor felt deliberate. No one should be surprised that the Poke was phenomenal. I shouldn't have arrived hungry. Even by Manhattan standards, it just was just too much money for too little food. The term "prix fixe" is used quite liberally as there is a $12 supplement for a tiny NY strip steak. If you want to ride the Poke wave, there are much cheaper options elsewhere. I don't see any other reason to go. The ambiance was nice enough, the service was good, and the bathroom was great, but at least in my eyes, that's not reason enough to drop close to $100 and leave with an empty stomach.

This place is good, and relatively unique.  I came here to celebrate with my fiance our anniversary, and it happened to be Restaurant Week.  The RW week menu here, is a good deal, where they actually showcase good dishes.  We were seated promptly, even though late for an 8pm ressie on a Sunday. Surprisingly, even as we were leaving the restaurant was pretty full. It also looks small but wraps around in the back so you can seat larger groups (it smelled weird back there, though). 3.75 stars, just rounding up because I think they are new.Anyway.  Here's what we had- He had the big eye tuna poke - great portion, fantastic taste  (fatty, crunchy, spicy) and we loved the seaweed salad- I had the silken tofu - Please note. Do NOT get this unless you really, really like roe, fish paste, uni... It was overall too fishy for me and didn't have enough tofu in it.  It made the dish really salty. Portions were good, for the most part.  We had for dinner;-He, the pork belly. Honestly, this sounded really delish and is a signature dish.  Soft, caramelized pork belly (yummy!) with mustard greens and pineapple. Yum. -I, the bluefish spaghetti.  Honestly, I love the lemon flavor but felt it was overall a wee bit... salty. And I am a salt freak.  And the fish didn't add much flavor. I would have loved a bit of spice...For dessert (arguably the best part)-He the sundae, with salty graham cracker (yummmy!), coconut ice cream, nuts, marshmallow flush (it seemed like). This was a delicious dessert, hands down.-I, the burnt orange ice cream with tapioca, red bean, dried fruit.  Definitely a winner but still has more experimental Asian funk I had a glass of crips Sav Blanc with my meal. They were great about water refill, and prompt with service.  I would recommend - especially if you're not familiar with Hawaiian but overall love Asian/Chinese/Japanese flavors.   My particular RW could have been a little too experimental and I wish the food was a bit more refined. But portions are not bad and prices on a regular day seem great so can't complain.

First, service is friendly and efficient but a restaurant is also about what comes out of the kitchen. This is where Noreetuh falls short, very very short. We had the tuna poke and Hawaiian hash with eggs and toast; both plates were unremarkable and overpriced. The tuna in the poke was average quality tuna - actually it was chewy. Doused in sesame oil, it lacked the umami flavor. The eggs and pork hash with overcooked sunny side up eggs and butter less wonder bread toast was worse than second rated diner food. Disappointed - we searched for another brunch meal to make up for such a bland dining experience.

Cute interiors. Silken tofu with uni and ikura was wonderfully fishy. Mentaiko pasta is delicious and buttery. Chocolate haupia sundae was not too sweet and had interesting flavors. Azuki bean and coconut tapioca was also not too sweet, and the textures made for a very unique dessert. Definitely recommend.

I went to Noreetuh the other night for Restaurant Week. Having lived in Hawaii, I was stoked to try the food (and planned out what I was going to order in advance). The poke was great - very fresh and I loved the macadamia nut crunch. Pork croquettes were awesome too - lightly friend with a tasty Katsu dipping sauce.I ordered the garlic shrimp over rice as my entree. To be honest, it was too salty, but my boyfriend had the teriyaki chicken which was tender and flavorful. We both had the haupia sundae for dessert which we loved.The service was excellent and the waiter was friendly. My water glass was always full and the meal was coursed well.

As a slight change of pace from my usual dining habits around this area and dining out in the full spirit of restaurant week (trying something new!) the SO and I went to Noreetuh for a weekday night dinner. The restaurant itself looks brand spanking new, everything was shiny and clean. Well-spaced dark wood tables, candles, and neutral walls. We sat towards the front of the restaurant next to the bar (which at the time of dining only had two stools there). We each took advantage of the three course prix fixe ($38) to try what Noreetuh had to offer.I started with the pork croquettes. Croquettes were good, fried well, starch-y but not anything too wildly different from what you would be able to get at a Japanese market. SO got the tuna poke which was really tasty! Would recommend that to start.For mains, I had a bass with asparagus; the SO the mentaiko spaghetti. The bass was crispy, executed well. The accompanying asparagus tasted vinegar-soy, not bad. The mentaiko spaghettie - was distinctly japanese with flakes of smoked butterfish mixed in.The desserts: haupia sundae, and azuki bean and tapioca float. the SO and I swapped as the haupia sundae tasted like a sundae and I really enjoyed the coconut ice cream graham cracker taste together. The azuki bean and tapioca float tasted like a toned down halo halo which is a good thing, cause halo halo is crazy. Even then the sweetness level on both desserts were excessive. Just overly sweet so much so that the nuances of the flavors get lost.Overall, Noreetuh is a nice place to grab dinner. Service was excellent, food was pretty good in a distinctly pacific island-ish way. Would certainly stop by again.

This was our second time at Noreetuh -- the first was for dinner, the second for brunch. Each time we had an noteworthy meal. Brunch was a combination of typical American cooking -- fried chicken with fried eggs, this an eastern accent (kimchei). There was a noodle dish, fish dish, waffles, etc. Lots of nice drinks on the menu. Service was very good, atmosphere had a nice vibe. Dinner is also noteworthy and worth exploring. The food is creative with strong eastern elements combined with many of the familiar American dishes and flavors.

Service at Nooretuh is excellent. They are very attentive, filling up your water glass and quick with catering to any needs that you may have. Their pork croquettes are very tasty along with the mentaiko spaghetti. The garlic shrimp over rice, lettuce and pineapple was also tasty, but wanted to see the pineapple infused with the rice instead of being on the side. Only issue with the place was that they use paper napkins.As a tip, don't ask for sriracha, they will give you chili paste instead.

A promising Hawaiian Japanese Korean Philippine restaurant. It is in the East Side in two tiny halls.   You walk in and it's like a funeral house, you are looking for the dead man.  And the worse is that they sit you in the back room, in front of a wall. A tuna can.Incredibly spicy, you feel how you start to bloat. The desserts are nominated for the worst dessert of New York. The waffles were inedible. The wine by the glass disastrous. It's like the typical restaurant that wants to stand out for their original menu, but the execution fails.  A bummer. Don't forget your Tums. It's acid food. Crummy. Aloha and good bye.

Hidden gem for this food critic from San Francisco. Noreetuh is genuinely incredible: well-realized and articulated flavors, elevated presentation (no surprise given the Per Se DNA in its founders), and extremely generous portions. Be sure to have the mentaiko spaghetti and pork belly. It's also the best-value prix fixe in the city: $38 for three courses and full sized portions across the board. Will be returning.

Tasty, unique small plates in a small, dimly lit restaurant. I particularly like the small plates for sharing with friends - they have unique flavors I haven't found elsewhere in NYC. I particularly recommend the corned beef tongue, which had a wonderful texture. As a chocolate and peanut butter fan, I really liked the mochi waffles; often chocolate/pb desserts can be heavy but these were light and great for sharing with a group of a few people. I would not recommend the crispy mushrooms, which were a bit too oily. The service was attentive and I'll definitely be back.

Great recommendation from a friend and we decided to check it out while in NYC.Food was an absolute hit. Food are innovative and well seasoned. Big eye tuna poke + silken tofu w uni were my favorites. The restaurant was fresh,cozy and clean.Place was dimly lighted so it was difficult to take photos. Portions for the entree at least for the halibut was kinda small.

Decor - Classy and dimly lit. It was more on the romantic side..Service - The waiters were very attentive.Appetizer - Silken Tofu, Uni, Ikura, Mushroom, Shiso ($12)This was full of many different flavors. The tofu was really soft. I personally wasn't a fan of it, but that's because there was too much going on for me. I'm glad I tried it though. Entree - Mentaiko spaghetti ($22) This was simply amazing. There was so much flavor in the spaghetti. I've never had pasta like this before. The waiter said it was the most popular dish, so I had to try it. The pasta had smoked butterfish pieces in it topped with crunchy..seaweed, and .. just wow. I would go back to the restaurant just to get this again. I was honestly so sad to have to share this dish with my friend. I wanted it all to myself!!!Dessert - Bruleed pineapple ($10)I'm not going to lie..I thought this was going to be a pineapple-flavored creme brulee LOL. So, I was very surprised to see that it was just a pineapple. Nonetheless, it was still very yummy. They toast the top of the pineapple, so you're eating chilled and toasted pieces at the same time. The pineapple pieces are lightly salted as well. That was a nice touch. I will definitely try putting salt on my pineapple in the future, although I'm not so sure if that's all it takes.The total bill came out to about $50 for 2 people. Not tooooooooo shabby. I want to come back to try the pork belly.

Coming from a Hawaiian childhood, I consistently crave Hawaiian foods.  While this is by no means authentic, it does combine some of the French expertise (Per Se veterans) with the influences of Japanese, Korean, and Hawaiian.While I do wish they served Spam Misubi, the corned beef tongue misubi is not too shabby.  I'm also a huge fan of the (overpriced) poke, though quality and taste is comparable to, if not better than the poke I have had back home.  The appetizers are tasty and reasonably priced.The food is 3.5 stars actually, but the service here is top notch.  They recognized me after two times in the restaurant, and hey, it's the little things that make you feel special.

Great to know that there's a Hawaiian restaurant in East Village.  It fits the description of Filipino,  Japanese, and Korean cuisines rolled into 1 restaurant. The tuna poke tasted really good; the spaghetti is exactly the same as the Filipino food, palabok; I love the chow noodles. Didn't get the chance to try their desserts because the $38 prix fixe menu is more than enough!

This place is good. The dishes are creative and tasty. I went with a friend and did the tasting menu (3 courses for $38 - big portions). The restaurant is modern but cozy with friendly staff. My favorite was the mentaiko spaghetti.Got to try 6 courses:Silken tofu with uni - yummy, unique, good uni.Fried mushrooms - skip, like tasteless bar food.Heart of palm salad - refreshing, hearty salad. Fluke sashimi - tried and true sashimi with a little kick.Mochi halibut - tasty/pleasant with familiar asian fusion flavors.Mentaiko spaghetti - smokey, delicious.

Liked it! From the moment I walked in, to the moment I walked out, it was a great experience. The staff are all friendly, laid back and very hospitable. FoodOrdered a bit too much for 2, but let's be honest.. no such thing as too much food. 1. monkfish liver torchon: ON POINT. Favorite of the night. do not miss this. this is a very "rich" dish. i recommend tasting the monkfish first without anything to truly appreciate the ensemble. once you did that, mash everything together and eat it with the bread they give you. Something I noticed though was that this dish can get "old" quick. They gave us 5 slices of amazingly soft bread but I think 4 would've been sufficient along with slightly smaller portions. By the 5th slice it got a little overwhelming. Besides that, excellent dish. 2. big-eye tuna po-ke: As P. Wells noted, it's not pronounced poke but po-ke, like okay. Not trying to be a snob but at least know what you're ordering. I didn't know what to expect but another winner. Big chunks of tuna with nutty flavors all around. 3. octopus poke: this, comparison to the tuna was ok. don't get both po-kes.4. silken tofu: slightly disappointed. all things uni are okay with me and while the tofu itself was great, for some reason the flavors didn't all come together. 5. mentaiko spaghetti: excellent. unfortunately we were too full to finish it but nonetheless the smoked butterfish was on point. Wine pairing: excellent. I'm no wine expert but each wine paired well with the dishes we got. I guess that's the point but the manager/super-tall friendly asian male host was very informative of why he chose x,y and z wine. Service: excellent all around. I think the host/manager really set the tone nicely for the entire restaurant. The staff were friendly, welcoming and seemed genuinely, happy. Would go back for date night, or special occasions. Worth venturing out to!

My friends and I came on a Friday night and ordered from the pre-fixed menu. The waitress mentioned it's the same size as the regular menu but a better discount. I'm unfamiliar with Hawaiian food but the food we ordered was delicious! I especially liked the silken tofu with uni. My least favorite dish was the garlic shrimp with rice. The waitress suggested it as it was a popular dish but the garlic was overpowering and I tasted it in my mouth for the rest of the night despite many mints.We stayed for a very long time on a Friday night but we never felt rushed! Definitely worth it to try once.

relatively new Hawaiian fusion restaurant which is unique to Manhattan and weird because these types of dishes are usually very cheap (were talking spam which is super low meat quality but everything here is pricier)---corned beef masubi: flavorful corned beef!---silken tofu: not bad, I liked the quality ingredients with uni and salmon roe but it was prob my least fav dish---pork croquettes: delicate fried crust! Loved the moist shredded texture of the pork inside but it def needed that dipping sauce---spam tortellini: unique and tasty take on tortellini free japanese gummy candy after your mealNOTE: Small restaurant so make RSVPS or snag a bar seat

My friends brought me here for my birthday.  I am a fan of Hawaiian fare so I was excited to check out the cuisine.  One of the best meals I have ever had.  We started with the taro chips (yum!!!) with truffles, spicy gobo and fluke.  I had mochi crusted halibut for my main and the mochi waffles for dessert.  I'm not a big wine drinker, but their wines are delicious.  Can't wait to go back and try their other dishes.  Impeccable service too.
Excellent and interesting menu, awesome wine pairing (that is a steal!) and great service. Would definitely recommend and will definitely be back.

I would give this place 4.5 stars. It's really fantastic, and with the $38 three course prix fixe it's one of the best values I've had in a really long time. The portions are large, especially by NYC standards. The food is flavorful and creative. The silken tofu with uni is not only gorgeous, but almost a masterpiece. The tuna poke and octopus poke are both VERY tasty. We also had the mochi encrusted halibut which was delightful. The fried mushrooms off of the snacks menu are yummy as well. The spam agnolotti, while tasty, is very rich with a heavy cream sauce--if you want to taste this, you should share it with someone else.Service is friendly and warm without being cloying.Highly recommend!

Perfection. A friend and I had dinner here recently and absolutely loved it. We got: the tuna poke, sashimi, and pork belly entrees. The dishes are amazing and the service outstanding.The manager (or owner?) went around to different tables to see if guests had questions about the menu, which was a nice touch. Also loved the sake we got and dessert.
Park croquetteSpaghetti with butterfly fishThe poki goes well with the croquetteAwesome service.  Wish I had room for the pineapple preme brûlée

I actually had quite a few of the dishes on the menu. The tuna poke was definitely my favorite. It's even been voted Top 100 dishes in NYC 2015 by Time Out New York. The surprise to me was the beef tongue. It tastes just like a really soft piece of beef. You just have to get pass the word tongue. The crispy mushrooms goes really well with a bottle of echigo. The pork croquette and pork belly was also very nice. For dessert, I'm a big chocolate guy so I had to pick the brownie with a scoop of coconut ice cream. The pudding and pineapple was also very good. The service was excellent. The staff really knows what they're doing. They don't encroach you too much like many places I've been to.

I'm currently relatively unschooled in Hawaiian cuisine, but not for long, as I'm planning on visiting the Big Island and Oahu in late Jan/early Feb. Our visit to Noreetuh turned out to be some very pleasant trip research.Even for a newbie like me, it's pretty easy to tell that the chefs here create sophisticated takes on traditional Hawaiian cuisine, with attention paid to both interesting/unique flavor profiles and the aesthetic. The restaurant features two different rooms, each with a different look but both with a modern, classy vibe. The place was relatively empty when we arrived around 7, and things started to pick up and get pretty noisy when we left at 8:30.I only had one item each off of the "snacks" and "mains" sections, and while I didn't leave hungry, I probably could've had a little more food. For the price, I thought the main dishes were a tad on the smaller side. But to be fair, I was realllly hungry when I arrived.I started with the tempura-flaked shishito peppers. I enjoyed these a lot, even though several times a particularly hot pepper left me panting and nearly incapacitated. Shishio peppers are not for the faint of tongue. Anyway, I liked that the tempura was in flake form and enhanced but didn't completely overwhelm the flavor of the pepper. My friend had the pork croquettes and the braised pork belly. I thought the croquettes were great, but didn't love the pineapple sauce on the pork belly.Since I'm trying to get into the Hawaii mood and islanders' love for spam is a well-known trope, I decided to try the spam agnolotti (burgundy truffles, celery, parmigiano-reggiano cream). There were a lot of distinct flavors in this dish, but I thought they blended together well. It was tangy, earthy, meaty and cheesy-creamy all at once. The truffles were sliced very thinly on top and provided the light, earthy flavor (don't expect that familiar intense truffle-y taste from a burgundy truffle). The tanginess came from something at bottom of the dish, although I'm not quite sure what (artichokes?). The spam, which was minced, was more understated than I thought.Since our trip isn't for another few months, I would definitely consider coming back soon and maybe trying some wine pairings this time.Overall, I thought Noreetuh was a 3.5-star experience and I'd give it that if I could.

Noreetah is a brand new gem in the EV. Loved the menu, the atmosphere, the corned beef app, the spaghetti and butterfish and the wine. Not terribly overpriced, not terribly loud, even on a Sat night at 9. Lovely. I am sorry but had to deduct a star, though, for our waitress's persistent up selling. It was quite obnoxious. After we ordered 2 entrees, an app, and 2 glasses of $14 wine, she said, "Are you sure you won't still be hungry?" She came back to pour the wine and said, "we actually recommend one app and one entree per person." Further, when trying to help us decide which app to order, she picked the most expensive. I'm sure they tell them to up sell but this was not cool. Even my ever-patient husband said, "whoa."

It's not hawaii, but its the best poke in NEW YORKWe had the Wagyu Beef - came with sweet potato greens and was delicious, melts in your mouth goodness, and the greens were fried just the way I like it. Pork belly- super tender came with sweet potatoes and peanutsBig Eye Tuna Poke - soo good, I've been to hawaii and theres this hole in the wall that makes amazing poke. I've been trying to find good poke in the city for the longest time and this place has made that happen! Also came with macadamia nuts! very hawaiin :DUni and tofu- The ingredients were very fresh, and there were just so many flavors, the roe was salty and the mushrooms were sour and the tofu just helped balance it outCorned Beef Tongue Musubi- Never had beef tongue but its interesting, it was pretty good! We left the restaurant stuffed and our bill came out to be around $100 including tip. Very reasonably priced.Presentation was greatCustomer Service was greatand they give you japanese gummy candies with your bill I'll be back!It is a hit or miss depending on what you order, and you need to be open to flavors

Wanted to give it a try since reviews were great to start.  Very wary on the Hawaiian concept but since I'm adventurous I thought it be fine.  Definite hits and misses.  Came in with one friend and sat in the side dining room, which is kind of janky compared to the main room.  Came with one friend and we ordered a recommended amount. We started with the corned beef tongue musubi - easily our favorite thing on the menu, basically a sushi roll with tender, fatty, corned beef and some peanuts.  Next as split the tuna poke and pork croquettes, the poke was light, refreshing and had a nice kick; the croquettes did not have the greatest consistency. We finished with the mentaiko spaghetti and garlic shrimp.  The spaghetti was quite lovely - interestingly fishy and the chilis add a great kick and texture.  The shrimp was absolutely horrible: no flavor, ugly plate, bland lettuce and raw pineapple.  Honestly, I wouldn't come back but enjoyed trying new things with a friend.  Could totally understand others who love this place, just wasn't for me.

Really good vibes and fantastic music. The tuna was on point and the ambiance was great. Friendly staff and yummy beers on tap. The wife was happy and so was I. If I'm in the area I'll definitely consider coming back.

This was unique experience. The cuisine description is Hawaiian but it's more a fusion of Hawaiian, Korean, Japanese and American. For starters we ordered the Portuguese sausage. There was a lot of flavor in the two patties garnished with sweet corn. Had the truffle taro chips. I wasn't a fan of it. But it was a good  Pulled pork croquette were a little bland. Came with a Katsu sauce but was a watery and needed more depth.  The main entree was a pineapple glazed pork belly.  The pork was so tender that the fat just melted in your mouth. It was garnished with peanuts and pickled swisschard. It was a good combination. But I would say the portions are on the small side. After a wine pairing and before tip came out to $100 and I left happy but still hungry. The reason for a solid 4 stars includes the service. They were attentive and my water was always full. The quality of the food is great. Would I go back? If I ate first I would.

We had the corned beef tounge roll and the tuna eye poke. Honestly its quite pricey and for the tuna poke, all the stuff they threw in distracted from the taste of fresh fish. I mean after that I didnt want to order anything and honestly the menu is quite small. Food wise too pricey and not that good I won't be back but I have to say the staff are very polite and friendly I very much appreciate that.

A-OK is a great way to describe Noreetuh. Self described as korean, hawaiian, japanese fusion, but Vicky described as having the flavors that I am familiar with but not quite executing it well enough to warrant it good fusion food. With these kinds of flavors, I prefer to just have them the good old fashioned korean, or hawaiian, or japanese way.For example - the Crispy Mochi Waffles, Whipped Peanut Butter, Alaea Salt. This was basically the chinese street style rice noodles adapted to a dessert. However, the mochi waffles did not have a good consistency, it was way too chewy. The whipped peanut butter was way too sweet, and although they tried to balance it out with some of that Alaea salt, it just didn't work. I would rather have my "dai pai dong" chinese rice noodles any day over this.So I felt this way about many of the dishes on the menu.I think the only thing I liked here were the Kalua Pork Croquettes, which were exactly how croquettes should be - perfectly fried, soft, with a delicious meat filling. Did it have a distinctive korean fusion flavor? No. Was it a good croquette? Yes.I guess what I'm trying to say is that the thought behind the dishes was amazing. I read the menu thinking my socks would be blown off. But, in reality the execution just wasn't there. The flavors didn't work together as a fusion dish as they do prepared in their original way. Just MHO.

I came here a bit early, so I sat at the bar. The bartender was very knowledgeable about their extensive wine list. Although it was more than I expected to spend, I ordered a glass (and another later) of their new Chardonnay .. it was beautiful. One my friend came in, we shared the tuna poke while waiting for the others. It was also very good, but I wish it was a larger size. For my entree, I ordered the spaghetti which was eye opening. It was cooked al dente with so many flavors I've never even imagined with spaghetti. It was so interesting and delicious. I definitely recommend this plate. The dishes took longer to cook, so they gave us a complementary plate of baked chips with truffle oil and seaweed. Who knew chips can taste so good? We ordered the pineapple and macadamia brownie for dessert. I wasn't too fond of it, but we received banana cake with pineapple ice cream on the house which was fantastic. The wait staff is attentive but not overwhelming. They were very polite and knew how to make us feel comfortable and at ease. We stayed a pretty long time, but I didn't feel rushed at all. Overall, all items (including wine) were priced on the higher end; however, I enjoyed each dish and I will definitely come back. I felt like I found a hidden gem.

Delightful. An experience. Fine dining made reasonable. Loved the Mochi Crusted Halibut and Pineapple Braised Pork Belly. The Chow Noodles were to my liking, possibly on the spicy side for others. Perfect wine pairing. Jin was a masterful sommelier, taking time for spot on descriptions of what our palates would taste. Elevated the experience to another level. Memorable night. Would definitely repeat.
Totally delicious and worth the hype. The space is small and clean, the service is excellent and the food is totally unique.

Beautiful food and a wait staff knowledgeable on what they serve and what to recommend based on what you tell them you like. Great atmosphere for after work drinks. I had so much to try but the stand out dishes for me were their chips, tuna starter, and the peanut butter waffles. So yummy!

The Good:- Food- Tuna Poke, Crispy Mushrooms, Pork Belly, spaghetti - it was all delicious and a great spin on traditional Hawaiian food. The only so-so dish was the bread pudding. The King's Hawaiian bread is so soft and delicate that it didn't quite hold up in texture.- Service - Everyone was very friendly and niceThe Not-So-Good:- The kitchen might just be a tad tooooo good. We ordered, ate and left in under 45 minutes. For a pricey meal for 2, it sure was speedy. At no point did we feel rushed by the staff themselves, but the 3 appetizers came out together in less than 5 minutes after ordering, then the entrees made an appearance immediately after. So we felt like we had to eat faster than we wanted to...what to eat first?...crispy mushrooms getting cold or misubi seaweed getting soggy...is there time for wine?!I will definitely go back. I will just wait to order each item separately :)

I was around East Village with a client and after the meeting decided to get some brunch.  I remember Noreetuh just started their brunch menu, been here numerous time for dinner, why not brunch?The restaurant just started their brunch menu so didn't expect too many people. I walked in and I was the first customer, but not for long. Right after I ordered my Hawaiian breakfast, families of 4 and 5 started coming in.  Seems like the clientele are repeat regulars which mean they are doing skomething right.  Service is always on key from the well trained staff.Now the food, I forgot to take pictures because I couldn't wait to dig in, Hawaiian breakfast yummmm: eggs over easy runny yolk, spam, sausage (incredible!), macaroni salad, kimchi, and of course rice, oh yeah Kona Beer, not brunch without alcohol.  If u are asian, or been to Asia, this is our version of comfort brunch food.  Who could not relate to this!! Only one thing I recommend would be a little bowl of soup? Am I pushing it? Why mess with perfection? All I can do is ask, pretty please? Miso soup maybe? GREAT JOB NOREETUH TEAM!!!

Exceptional food & service!Came here with a friend for a birthday dinner. We started with the Kalua Pork Croquettes which were absolutely delicious and is a perfect starter before your entree. As an entree we got the Venison for two. It takes about 45 minutes to prepare but definitely worth every minute! The food was overall super delicious and the service was great! Not too overbearing, but made sure everything was okay with us. Definitely recommend coming here and I would love to come here brunch on a Saturday or Sunday!

It's a small cozy restaurant but has more room in the back. We ordered the big eye poke, pork croquette and the mentaiko spaghetti between two girls with some beers.The food was mediocre, nothing to write home about. The service was good. Friendly and attentive.

Two words: Love it!Wanted to try other starters but the person I was with didn't want any raw dishes but we had the croquette to start. It was definitely a great starter and I highly recommend it and I have to go back to try the other starters for sure.For the main dish, we ordered the venison for two. It takes 45 minutes to cook but well worth the wait.  The server will come out with the venison to show you that it's under the process and when it comes out, it's separated for two. 2 pieces each person served with my favorite, heirloom tomatoes. Each bite was mesmerizing. The service was very very on point. Everyone was polite and friendly. We weren't drinking so we didn't really need to be checked up as often but everyone was nice. The manager was very catering and he made sure everything was smooth. I heard they have a pretty awesome brunch menu so will definitely be back to check that out.The prices are very fair and so are the portions. The decor is really nice and the restaurant is very very clean (a important factor to be taken into consideration). All in all, this was definitely on my list and glad to say that I'd be back for more!

Great addition to NY. There isn't many hawaiian places here but this place is great! Fairly small place, small dishes and a bit on the pricey side but it was good food. We had the tuna tartar which was good. I had the pork belly as my entree and its as so tender and full of flavors. I highly recommend ordering this. My boyfriend had the halibut and it was okay. For dessert we had the bread pudding and the waffle crusted mochi, both great!

Very, very unique and super tasty!We shared all of the plates (which is definitely the way to do it).  My favorites were the tuna, beef tartar, pork belly, noodles, and especially the crispy mushrooms.  We also tasted the octopus, pork belly and tarto chips, which weren't as note worthy.  The desserts were great (and definitely worth saving stomach space for!).  In addition to loving the mochi waffles with peanut butter, we were also served a complimentary flambe pineapple - which was delicious (and very thoughtful).

After 11pm they move to a late-night menu.  I found this out the hard way on my first visit there, but basically their only item on the late night menu - SAIMIN - did not disappoint!  The saimin here was as good as any I've had on the islands - Aiea Bowl, Zippy's, I'd put Noreetuh's up against all of 'em, so kudos to these cats for gettin' it right.  The pork belly they put in there is crack and you've gotta add the soft egg.  I'm not even sure why it's not just included and you have to ask for it as an addition.  People who don't eat eggs?  C'mon brah.They're starting a weekend brunch that will serve spam, portuguese sausage, and .... you had me at spam.  That JFK to HNL bridge just got a little more legit with this addition to NYC methinks.  I'm eager to try their regular menu at some point, but thumb up for late night saimin and the brunch looks promising.  I mean, all we had around here for awhile for local grindz was L&L downtown and that was just garbage.Chee hoo!

Hype and (Per Se) resumes aside, it all just comes down to great food that's different without being pretentious. I loved everything we had last night -- silken tofu with uni, beef tongue masubi, some sort of pepper tempura, pork belly, mentaiko pasta, tuna poke, chow noodles, creme brulee pineapple, mochi waffles -- but I think the masubi and poke are must haves.

Noreetuh meets the hype- great flavors and creative spin on Japanese, Korean and Filipino cuisines.  Led by Thomas Keller-trained chefs at Per Se, Noreetuh is just great food in a chic yet casual setting.  I would recommend ordering a variety of various dishes and enjoy Family-style with your Dining party- this will be the best way to see how Noreetuh goes wide and deep with their uniquely creative Asian Fusion focus.  We enjoyed the following dishes that were all stellar:  truffle taro chips, beef tongue musubi, octopus poke, braised pork belly, mentaiko spaghetti, spam agnolotti and the King's Hawaiian bread pudding.

Noreetuh gets five stars for three reasons:1) The staff at Noreetuh is extraordinarily nice2) How many places do you know serving Hawaiian-influenced food?3) How many places do you know serving Hawaiian-influenced food that is both beautiful and delicious?I can't emphasize point one enough.  From the moment we walked in every single member of the staff had a huge smile and a neighborly demeanor.  We were not disappointed by the food, for which you can find a breakdown of the dishes we ordered below.SnacksCorned beef tongue musubi - a well-balanced bite that has encouraged me to try more beef tongue dishesSilken tofu - I don't usually enjoy tofu, but am hugely sensitive to food textures and this was a true representation of the word "silken" - yumStartersBig-eye tuna poke - impeccable presentation and a clean, fresh flavorMainsPineapple braised pork belly - if I had to big a favorite bite of the meal, it was the pork bellySpam agnolotti - inventive and tastyDessertsCrispy mochi waffles - a peanut butter lover's paradise (it's a heavier dessert, though, so make sure you save room!)My only regret of the evening was not having the opportunity to try the monkfish liver torchon or the mentaiko spaghetti, but there's always next time!

My dining companions may stumble on this review. I recommend coming here with adventurous eaters without dietary restrictions. One friend doesn't eat pork; both were turned off by beef tongue.We walked in on Friday around 7pm without a reservation. Despite it being August, another restaurant was packed solid by 6:30pm. In the East Village. They only sat the 3 of us when the party was full but after we were seated there was a guy that was seated at the table next to us. His dining companion didn't arrive for a while.- I had the beef tongue musubi on my own. I liked it. Nice play on spam musubi. There were nuts? that added to the texture.- Mushroom tempura w/ aioli - excellent- Fried shishito peppers - ok.- Taro chips with truffle - good. Get it.- Octopus poke - I liked it. My friends said it was fishy.- Tuna poke - Fine too but I liked the octopus more.- Garlic shrimp - Hmm... this should've been better. Not garlicky enough. Pineapple wasn't ripe and sweet enough. Nowhere near the North shore shrimp trucks.- Mentaiko pasta. One friend liked it. My taste buds felt muddled - it wasn't that good to me. **Edit - I had it again and stand by my decision**- Mochi waffle dessert with peanut butter and honey. The waffle wasn't good on its own. And the peanut butter didn't make it much better. - Chocolate haupia sundae was ok. I would've liked it more with less graham cracker.Service was excellent. I'm not itching to return any time soon but will definitely do some research before the next visit and bring someone people who are more adventurous. I totally wanted to try the spam agnolotti. In general, I love Hawaiian food but felt like it lacked something.

Fresh and inventive - a memorable experience.My boyfriend and I went here on a last minute date night--so we went for the early bird special, around 6pm. That didn't matter--the service was as attentive and sincere as if we were high priority. Treated from beginning to end. We ordered taro chips with truffle, but we got the crispy mushrooms gratis. I think he knew we were eyeing them. We were a bit predictable with the tuna poke, but we also got the steak tartare, which was phenomenal (that's coming from me, when that's really my bf's favorite dish). Pork belly usually makes me want to pass out, but this one was melt in your mouth, perfect balance with greens and a starch. It was delicious and decadent without being excessive. We paired that with the summer vegetable pasta, which was light and perfect, and took home as leftovers and are eating right now. It's still good.The most admirable feat was the server making our bottle of wine last the whole meal without ever feeling like we were low or moving too quickly. Excellent pacing.We finished with the brûlée'ed pineapple, which was an on-point, simple, sweet ending. And a dessert wine, served by one of the founders / owners, who was extremely personable and open.Couldn't recommend it more. A great break from the typical NYC fare. Enjoy.

Simple on the outside yet complex in the inside. This place is an intimate mystery. A good mix of people and genuine service that's always ready to give you what you want and take away what you don't need. Hosted by a gentleman GM, Jin, is passionate about his food and quality of service. Been here twice now! I'll keep coming!! This place is fancy Hawaiian with a working class price!

I was grateful to be able to try out Noreetuh given all the hype it has received since its inception. It is a very "trendy" restaurant, with no signs on the exterior. It was very crowded on a Thursday night. The food was presented artfully and the ingredients were top-notch, but the taste was not super inspiring. I ordered the taro chips because of other positive Yelp reviews. I was not impressed. The flavor and crunch were nice but they were definitely not worth $11, more like $5. The miso mushroom starter was a standout. The flavors were very evident and it was the perfect size for a starter. My entree, the chow noodles, was the only option I had since I'm a vegetarian. I wasn't impressed with it either. There were tons of vegetables in it but they all had the same texture as the noodles. The spiciness was perfect and not overpowering (this is coming from a white girl who cannot handle spicy!) I would have liked to see more options for vegetarians on the menu. What was really incredible was the bread pudding with pineapple ice cream. It was one of the better restaurant desserts I've ever had.
