Definitely order it if you like bread pudding!            Honestly, I'm not sure if I would come back here. It is definitely better suited for meat eaters as there are many options. The vegetarian entree option is kind of weak. I was excited for a dish with a Hawaiian flair (granted, I've never been to Hawaii so I'm not sure exactly what that would entail) but the noodle dish seemed more pan-Asian and not really distinctively Hawaiian (again, I have no authority on this subject but this is what I'm going to presume). It's a pretty pricy place. I understand that the chefs are derived from Per Se but looking at this restaurant holistically, I think the prices are unjustified.
Exceptional food quality, excellent customer service and reasonable prices for food and service. First time I've been to this place. Would strongly recommend to go there!!

When one thinks of "Hawaiian food" the unfortunate associations are to tikis, platters of food fried to unrecognizable oblivion, and tacky sugary drinks with umbrellas.  If that's your desire, Noreetuh is not for you.  Noreetuh is New American with heavy Hawaiian and Pacific Rim influences.  Take for example a standard Hawaiian appetizer, poke (pronounced like the "pokey" of "hokey pokey"), which is sashimi grade fish that is akin to tuna tartare and not ceviche, the latter which has citrus juice in it.One does not have to be Hawaiian to appreciate the gracious and attentive service of Noreetuh.  Certainly being from Hawaii helps one recognize the local influences of Spam that is sneaked into the torteloni and the Kings Bakery Hawaiian sweet bread made into a pudding.  But one just has to be a good eater to appreciate the flavors of truffle dusted taro chips and the mentaiko spaghetti.  It's been weeks since I dined there and I still can't get the flavors of the mentaiko spaghetti out of my mind, briny, creamy, salty, all at once. Check them out.  You'll be glad you did even though there' nary a tiki or torch in sight.

A lot of previous reviewers have taken note of Noreetuh's Per Se pedigree. We thought the three co-owners' training was abundantly clear in the service (warm, professional, detail-oriented) and the food (inventive, beautiful, and above all, delicious). We ordered quite a few snacks and starters, two main courses, and dessert to share: - seaweed chips (salty, sweet and completely addictive for those of us who enjoy seaweed to begin with, but made no converts of the dining companions who didn't already eat seaweed) - corned beef tongue musubi (great combination of flavors, beautifully cured corned beef, one of our favorites) - silken tofu with uni, shiitake, shiso (reminded me of a summery chawanmushi, delicious and beautiful to look at) - soft-shell crab with tomato salad, pipikaula, calamansi mayonnaise (juicy, fat, crab with a truly standout tomato salad; those tomatoes were sweet as candy) - grass-fed beef tartare with smoked egg yolk, daikon, wonton chips (the smoked egg yolk was the best thing I've eaten in months, maybe all year, and it elevated an already fantastic beef tartare to something ethereal, as good as anything you'd have at Per Se) - big-eye tuna poke with macadamia nuts, pickled jalapeño, seaweed (perfectly balanced in terms of flavor, textures; one of my favorites on the menu) - monkfish liver torchon with pear, cilantro, passionfruit, hawaiian roll (another Per Se worthy dish whose unbelievable richness and presentation strongly recalled foie gras; do NOT miss this dish if you enjoy or have ever enjoyed a liver preparation)- mochi-crusted halibut with pole beans, chinese bacon, fermented black bean (very fresh fish, crispy crust, kick ass pole beans that were perfectly sweet and salty and umami rich from the hint of black bean sauce) - duck breast with apricot kernels, purslane, li hing mui (I was too full to try this dish, but my dining companions enjoyed it) - crispy mochi waffles with whipped peanut butter, honey (waffles had a really interesting, light, crispy texture; whipped peanut butter tasted like a well-made mousse) This was stellar food and stellar service -- and an unusually good value. We were so impressed with our meal that we wouldn't be surprised if Noreetuh were a NYC institution ten, twenty or thirty years down the line. It's better than most of the Momofukus (and probably tied with Ko). It is better than most one-starred Michelin restaurants in this city. If you care about food, you should run, not walk, to Noreetuh before some restaurant reviewer writes something that makes it impossible for mere mortals to score a seat at this restaurant.

I really don't know what the hype is about the place. Firstly, the decor is hideous. You would expect a hip new restaurant to at least have a charming interior, but the interior design is a real eyesore. I wish I could tel you what I ordered but everything was so damn forgettable. My bet is that people only like this spot because Hawaiian cuisine is hard to come by. Spare your appetite, it's not worth it. Huge disappointment.

It was good but not great. We ordered a bunch of items off the menu but nothing really stood out as amazing. The big-eye poke was probably the best item. I normally love sea urchin but was underwhelmed here. The mentaiko spaghetti was fine but also not the best. Nothing was terrible but with so many places in the city, I would prefer elsewhere.

Came here on a Saturday night for dinner at 6:00pm.  We were seated immediately and the staff was very polite.  We ordered the Corned Beef Tongue Musubi as an appetizer.  For entrees, we ordered the Mochi-Crusted Halibut and Duck Breast.  We also ordered King's Hawaiian Bread Pudding and Crispy Mochi Waffles for dessert.  The appetizers and both entrees were delicious!  The desserts were decent.  I would come back here again and recommend it to friends.  It's a nice date spot and I like the ambiance.

I'd read about Noreetuh in the same article that I'd heard about Oiji (just across the street), so I was eager to visit once I'd had dinner at Oiji not so long ago. This past weekend, we made the trek over to 1st Avenue for a relatively early dinner seating (6:15 PM); by the time we walked out closer to 8, the restaurant itself was filled up...so come early, or make a reservation! The restaurant is deceptively small when you enter; there is an entire dining area to the right behind the bar that is basically the same size as the space you see when you come in. The decor is intimate but austere - some mirrors line the walls but little else. I am disappointed to say that unlike Pete Wells, I didn't have the privilege (or lack thereof) of hearing any Taylor Swift songs playing in the background...that said, most of the music was contemporary pop (but not super-recognizable). The service was quick as well, with food and drinks being brought promptly, with our water glasses always filled. There are no cocktails, which was a bit saddening, and the beer selection is a little on the tight side - although I did appreciate having a Belgian-brewed Belgian IPA on tap.We ended up sharing all the dishes and doing a couple bites from the 'snacks' and the appetizer section each (what is the difference? Mainly size, but I think by any sensible definition, they are all appetizers) and splitting one entree. I'm glad the waitress was straight with us and said that was plenty - we wanted to add another appetizer, but that would have been pushing our luck. We started out with the musubi and the silken tofu for our small bites. I enjoyed the musubi a bunch; while it may not be as debasingly delicious as it would be with Spam, the beef tongue had great firm texture, and the curing of the beef gave it a nicely light acidic touch without being overbearing and taking away from the flavor of the meat. As for the tofu - I really enjoyed it, although I think the sauce was a bit much, and the mushrooms included were verifiably oversalted. It was one of those dishes where a bite or two was great, but polishing off half of it had me sipping aggressively on the water afterwards. For the 'starters', we did the tuna poke and the pork croquettes. Poke is as Hawaiian a dish as it gets, and they did a great job with it here. The tuna was pretty fresh, and I really enjoyed the crunchiness of the macadamia nuts and particularly the subtle heat from the marinated slices of jalapeno. I enjoy my poke with some flavors in it (my thought being - if I really want top-notch raw tuna, I'll go to a sushi joint), and this definitely had it in spades. I was more disappointed in the croquettes; while the Kalua pork was definitely juicy, it lacked much flavor on its own. The katsu sauce added a BBQ-style flavor that helped out, but I've made more flavorful Kalua pork in my slower cooker at home - so this was a bit of a strike against a spot influenced by Hawaiian cuisine. For our sole main dish, we did the mochi-crusted halibut. I liked the swath of squash puree that had a bright flavor, and the fish was cooked perfectly - very juicy flakes, and the mochi crust gave it a nice texture without interfering with the natural flavoring of the fish at all. To top the meal off, we went with the macadamia nut brownie with coconut ice cream. It's a tropical twist on a classic American dessert, and it worked out really well. The brownie was good (a tad on the dry side), but the coconut ice cream gave it a very refreshing feel without having a coconut flavor that was too overbearing. It wasn't overly heavy, either, making it a perfect way to finish off a (slightly) large meal.Although I think Noreetuh didn't quite measure up to its similarly new Asia/Pacific-inspired companion across the street, it was still a delicious meal that had a casual feel to it but with above-quality ingredients and preparation. There are plenty of other items on the menu I'd be interested in trying, and given how laid-back it is (and reasonably-priced, at least for NYC), I'd recommend to give it a shot. You won't feel like you're back in the Islands, but it will make you forget that you're in the hustle and bustle of East Village for a little bit.

I loved my experience at Noreetuh. Dined on a Wednesday around 8:30 PM with a friend. We ordered the Tuna Poke and Softshell Crab starters, both were delicious! The soft shell crab was lightly battered and came with some light aioli and vegetables which balanced the fried part nicely. The poke was tasty as well!For entrees, we shared the Mentaiko pasta and the Pineapple Pork Belly. Again, really happy with both of these. Very rich dishes, but we shared them and loved both. The pasta was in an oil based sauce and had some fish roe mixed in, I believe. The pork belly was well cooked and flavorful. Finally, for dessert, we shared the mochi waffles and the bread pudding. I would recommend the bread pudding over the waffles, though they were unique. I preferred the ice cream/bread pudding combo. The wine list was impressive though we did not drink with dinner. Service was very good! Prompt and friendly. Overall, would definitely come back here for a nice meal and looking forward to seeing how the menu changes.

I went here for dinner on a Sunday night with my boyfriend. The decor is really nice I like it. My boyfriend said they could work on the lighting though. The service was really great too.We got the crispy mushrooms which were a nice starter snack. The sauce was tasty.We got the tuna poke too which was good and the nuts were a nice edition. We also got the maintako spaghetti and braised pork belly which was good too.The food was all delicious but it wasn't as complex or creative as I would have expected. I wasn't wowed.We got for dessert the mochi waffles and the bread pudding. I loved the mochi waffles because I love mochi. The whipped sweetened peanut butter and honey was amazing. My boyfriend really liked the pineapple ice cream with his dessert but the raisins on top of the bread pudding were liked taking a shot of rum. They didn't cook out the alcohol so he couldn't eat them. Also with the prices I probably wouldn't go back. Definitely a must try though.

You walk in to a nice modern restaurant with dim candle lighting. We ordered the beef tongue masubi as an appetizer and the big eye tuna poke as a starter. I think they are good but not great. Even then, the portions are good (not large) and best for sharing between 2-3 people. The best part is the entree. I had the Garlic shrimp on rice and it comes with pineapples. It brought me back to the shrimp truck experience in Hawaii...seriously!! My husband had the pork belly and it was definitely slow cooked for a good long while, everything was tender and juicy. I had Mochi waffle for dessert and that was a good way to end the meal. I'd like to see them do a good loco moco in the future. I guess I don't need to go to Brooklyn for Hawaii food now ;)Ps - bathroom is a 1 stall only but very spacious and clean!

Noreetuh's been on our list for awhile since we've always wanted to try Hawaiian and where better to start than somewhere opened by a per se alum (other than Hawaii of course). Definitely feeling underwhelmed by our meal... Seems to be a collection of well executed dishes, but very little unique flavoring that differentiates it as Hawaiian fare. Appetizer:Corned Beef tongue mitsubi - a little too salty since the tongue is to replace spam. But enjoyed the peanuts and cilantro sauce to pair. Tuna poke - definitely recommend, pickled jalapeño adds a nice twist with some heat. Good starter to your meal. Entree:Chow noodles - great texture on the chewy noodles, morels absorbed butter exquisitely. Every bite with morels delivered super umami deliciousness.Garlic shrimp - while shrimp was done well, the dish overall fell flat with little creativity. If you're itching for a new place to try out in the area, definitely stop by. But if you're looking for a great Hawaiian meal, this may not be it.

I really wanted to like this place more, but it just didn't do it for me. The biggest turn-off was the prices. While not terribly expensive, the portions were quite small for the price.Kombu Chips: Bleh. I think that maybe I just don't like kombu. The seasoning was nice but these left my whole party of 7 with a terrible aftertaste in our mouths.Beef Tartare: Great! I prefer my tartare lightly dressed which this was, so I really appreciated that. This is something that I felt like I could get anywhere, though.Monkfish Liver Torchon: This was definitely our favorite appetizer of the night. It was incredibly unique, and the pairing of the passion fruit with the monkfish liver was perfect. If I ever came back here, it would be for this dish.Tuna Poke: Tuna was fresh but it tasted overwhelmingly of sesame. The flavors needed to be more balanced.Mentaiko Spaghetti: Okay, this dish was super weird. The butterfish was a nice touch and the pasta was cooked perfectly al dente, but I can't help but wonder who decided that mentaiko should be turned into a sauce and put over pasta. The flavors were nice though, and the aonori added a lot here.Mochi-Crusted Halibut: I was really disappointed. The crust was yummy but the fish was slightly overcooked and a little on the dry side. The sauces were alright but I felt like I didn't need squash puree and black bean-pine nut puree on the same plate. Also, it only came with 3 tiny pieces of bok choy. If we hadn't ordered appetizers we definitely still would have been hungry after this entree.Spam Agnolotti: THIS. This dish was absolutely incredible. The texture of the spam filling inside the pasta was so interesting, and the pasta was thin and flavorful. These were perfectly cooked and the sauce complimented them perfectly. Again, portion was smaller than it should have been.Honestly, skip dessert. The pineapple brûlée was super average, and for the $8 we all definitely could have gone without the quarter of a cold pineapple with browned sugar on top.The waitress was very friendly and the ambience was nice. I enjoyed the meal overall but wouldn't come back, simply because I know I can get a better meal for this price elsewhere.

I was really looking forward to trying Noreetah. I lived in Hawaii for 8 years and I'm also half Korean. I went and tried something from the finger food, starters, and entrees. Everything was so salty! Too salty :( I really want to continue to desert but just couldn't. I did however love my Santa Barbra Chardonnay. All in all I wouldn't go back.

Noreetuh was a good meal for a very reasonable NYC price. I went with my girlfriend and we split a bottle of Piuze, Terroir de Chichee ($53). The wine was delicious, smooth, and fruity. To start we split the Big-eye tuna poke and the hearts of palm salad. Both were intriguing dishes with Hawaiian taste and beautiful plating. The hearts of palm salad consisted of cleanly cut beets and hearts of palm served over a smoked tofu puree with crispy shallots sprinkled atop. It was one of the better dishes of the night. The Big-Eye tuna poke was good, but nothing over the top original. The tuna wasn't cut very cleanly and made for some strange bites, but the flavor was good. For dinner I ordered the Garlic Shrimp over Rice. The shrimp was cooked perfectly, as was the rice, and tasted exactly as the menu described. However, the presence of the dish was butchered by a side salad of undressed romaine lettuce. My girlfriend was nice enough to let me taste her dish, the Mentaiko Spaghetti, and I was glad that I did. It was superb. The flavors of the fish absorbed into the pasta and created a dish that felt true to the Hawaiian title. For dessert we split the Bread Pudding. Not too mushy but not too decadent. It almost tasted like French toast with a side of pineapple ice cream, which doesn't taste bad, but I expected a little more flare from ex-Per Se chef Chung Chow. Overall, the food was good, and again the prices were reasonable. The restaurant was small but comfortable (one room is clearly more enjoyable than the other). The food was good but needs to be tightened up. Being a new restaurant I have high hopes that these dishes can be fine tuned to make for a wonderful dining experience in the heart of the East Village.

The staff is nice, place is sweet but the food and drink overpriced and just okayOk I'm vegetarian so had only the vegetarian dishes - everything was lackluster  And the wine pour seriously maybe 3 ounces for 12$ !!

It's interesting to see how vastly different these 4 star yelp reviews are compared with Eater's review (ny.eater.com/2015/6/16/8…). I'm going to have to side with Eater on this one. I'm a believer in constructive criticism and for that I am rating 2 stars hoping the restaurant improves upon what is being said here.It was refreshing to experience a Hawaiian taste here in the city, but the food had a range poor execution to wonderful flavors. for snacks and appetizers:Monkfish liver torchon- tasted great, was like a Pâté spread on these miniature pieces of slightly toasted, buttered breadSilken tofu with uni - recommendedbig eye tuna poke - recommendedfor mains:pineapple braised pork belly - this was cooked really wellmentaiko spaghetti - this was really goodchow noodles - personally found this mediocre at best, you can find better at chinese takeout garlic shrimp over rice - while full of flavor, it was over the top heavy on garlicduck breast - this was pretty goodmochi crusted halibut - this was completely bland. the sauces offered nothing to the dish
A truly incredible experience!  Waitstaff was very warm & friendly & service was overall excellent.  Food was beyond delicious & very creative.  Highly recommend!

The food is very good and very interesting!  The place was packed so we sat at the bar. We had the pork croquettes which were crispy and not greasy.  I loved the beef tongue musubi, but my husband just liked it.  We both loved the heart of Palm and beet salad.  The salad was clean and refreshing.  The halibut had mochi crust which made it very crispy and good! We had every dessert on the menu. Our favorite was the pineapple and the brownie.  Just as awesome as the food was the wine list.  A good portion of the list is well priced and interesting.   Unfortunately, I am not a wine connoisseur so I don't remember the champagne and white wine we had, but the white wine was a burgundy and priced at $60 (we were splurging a little celebrating first time out after baby) I think and was great!  We recommend making a reservation because we were lucky to get 2 of the last 4 bar seats available.

I had wanted to check this place out because I was interested in the idea of taking a cuisine that is typically very hearty and comfort food-y and making it upscale. It's a small space, but the decor is modern and simple with zero kitsch or gimmicks. There was an impressive beer and wine menu, but I'll admit I was slightly disappointed that there no fun Hawaiian-themed cocktail list. Everything on the menu looked appealing, so to help us decide the waitress gave us her recommendations:-Tongue Musubi: Loved this- the tongue was very tender and it was well complimented by the crunchy sweetness of the crushed peanuts-Silk tofu with Uni and Ikura: actually wasn't a huge fan of this dish and was probably the only miss of the meal. I love tofu, uni, and fish roe  separately, but together it came out to be too briny and mushy for my taste-Tuna poke: delicious and fresh, could've given a bit more tuna to veggie ratio, but great flavors-Mochi-crusted fluke: Light and flaky with good sauces that complimented it-Pineapple braised pork-belly- SO good, I'm a huge pork belly fan and this had the perfect melt-in-your-mouth fat to lean meat ratio. It was tender and juicy and came apart easily.-Bread pudding - Warm and soft bread pudding that contrasted well with creamy ice cream with small pineapple bits in it...great combinationHawaiian food itself is so diverse, and is a fusion cuisine in itself. The menu at Noreetuh takes a creative and modern reinvention of the cuisine, and is a reflection of the Per Se chefs that brought it together. The flavors and plating are sophisticated and well thought out. If you like unique and flavorful food, I'd definitely recommend coming here!

Came here last night and had a wonderful time. Service: 5 starsFood: 3.75Ambience/decor: 5 Our waitress Allia (?) was amazing, warm, professional and kind. We were reset promptly for every course, kindly guided through the menu, and had just the right amount of conversation with her. Everyone else, from the busboys to the host, was also great. (It also didn't hurt that I bartend at a Patina Group restaurant, and one of the chefs used to work for Lincoln Ristorante)The ideas behind the food were all really good, but not everything succeeded. Tuna Poke:By far the most delicious thing we had that night. Pretty fresh tuna, marinated in a vinegary liquid with all sorts of things, like seaweed, folded in. The dish was intricate, tangy, delicious, and kept us coming back until the last bite. Monkfish Liver Torchon:The overall dish, with the passion fruit compote and the soft King's Hawaiian bread was good but not great. Everything together was much too sweet, and the liver paté itself was just blah. Spam Agnolotti:My least favorite dish of the night. The taste of preserved lemon overwhelmed everything, and I didn't find the spam to be "transformed" as some yelpers suggested. Mentaiko Spaghetti:So so so so good. That smoked butterfish just works so well, and the buttery (but not creamy) sauce was beyond addictive. Bread pudding:Yummm. Sweet and warm bread pudding balanced out with rum raisin and tart pineapple ice cream. Drinks:His gruner was wonderful. My rosé was just ok. Overall a very cool and fun dining experience; a restaurant that makes you feel welcome with both its warm service and chic but cozy ambience.

This was my second favorite spot that I went to during my NYC trip. Though I am not sure how much I paid because my team paid for it, I enjoyed many of the dishes. We had everything on our preset menu. They were also very accommodating and offered many variety for vegetarians because my co-worker left full and satisfied.Snacks-- Truffle taro chips: one of my favorite dishes because I killed it quick lol. The taro chips were thin, so they didn't fill me up before the main courses, and the truffle complemented the chips very well.- Crispy mushrooms with sweet miso sauce: usually not a fan of mushrooms, but this one tasted delicious all crispy with the sauce - definitely recommend to order if you're a mushroom fan.- Spicy gobo: Not a fan of mushrooms so this dish was ok to me. Everyone around me loved it because it wasn't heavy, and the crispiness and sauce paired with the mushroom as the salad was a bit hit for my table.- Kombu chips: This was probably my least favorite snack that we got. It is seaweed that's made into chips with a spicy flavoring - it had an odd taste to it, which I was not digging. Starters-- Hearts of palm, beets, crispy shallots, cilantro, and smoked tofu: also wasn't a fan of the smoked tofu. It had a very familiar taste, but I'm usually not into anything into this dish so I tried it and passed on it.- Big-eye tuna poke: This was my favorite of the starters. It was very tasty and flavored well. The tuna melted in my mouth, yum!- Kalua pork croquettes: Nothing really special about this but that it is like pork dipped in katsu sauce. Mains-- Chow noodles: Probably my favorite dish of the mains - noodles were soft and the veggies were good.- Halibut: soft and tasty fish with good flavoring, but it wasn't something that stood out to me or special.- Pineapple braised pork belly: tasted good but it was very fatty, which I am not usually a fan of, but it was rich in flavor.Desserts-- Macadamia nut brownie with coconut ice cream: the brownie was a bit hard, but I really liked the coconut ice cream.- Bruleed Pineapple: I liked this one best out of both desserts because it was different. It had a sugar glaze on top of half a pineapple, like the sugary layer on top of creme bruelee! Though it was just pineapple underneath it, it was different and delicious.Definitely recommend :) The pinot noir was also good there because it didn't have a strong aftertaste!

Appetizers we ordered included the spicy gobo, silken tofu with uni, monkfish liver torchon, and tuna poke. The monkfish liver was surprisingly the group's favorite. It's very similar to pate and was delicious. The tuna poke and tofu with uni were also great.Of the entrees, my favorite was the mochi-crusted halibut which was cooked just right. Others preferred the pineapple braised pork belly. The most disappointing was the spam agnolotti, which didn't taste like much of anything.For dessert, we shared the bruleed pineapple and the crispy mochi waffles, which were both so tasty and fun to eat. I'd also recommend checking out their Rieslings, as we shared one that was fantastic.

The food was very good, a tad bit sweet on almost everything though.  I suppose the touch of sweetness in everything is expected given the cuisine.  My favorite was the monkfish liver - it had a passionfruit purée under it and was served with toasted Hawaiian rolls.  It was rich with a little tang.  My least favorite was the chow noodles - just tasted like soy sauce stir fried noodles with a mix of greens - I think it could be improved with some ginger for a punch.  The two other dishes fell somewhere in the middle - silken tofu with sea urchin and mushrooms, and the tuna poke.  I liked them both very much.  I had the Mochi waffles with peanut butter and honey for dessert - it was delicious, it a bit too sweet.  The Mochi waffle was very light and crunchy - really had no taste other than the peanut butter and honey on top.  The waffle almost looks plastic because it's so white, but it was a surprisingly good combination.  I'd love to see them add Hawaiian shaved ice with red bean, lychee, condensed milk - the whole shebang of toppings mmmmm :9...Overall, it was a very good experience - food was great, service was attentive, and my only complaint was the noise level.  They could use some type of decor to absorb some sound, had to shout to my dinner companion to be heard.  I'd go back for the monkfish liver and I still think about those waffles.

Given the sheer amount of coverage that Noreetuh's gotten over the past few weeks, there are very few people who haven't heard of the cozy East Village restaurant. Started by two Per Se vets (manager Jin Ahn, executive chef Chung Chow), the restaurant takes a modern, playful spin on Hawaiian cuisine, best evidenced in the fact that "Noreetuh" translates into "Playground" in Korean.The space isn't the most ideal, though. The dining room is split into two divided sections, and tables are tightly packed with minimal walking space between them. The lengthiness and narrowness of such a layout also means that sunlight is a very precious commodity, and darkness settles faster than at most venues (which may be a benefit to some diners). My group of three were seated in the second room, and our server was quick to fill our glasses with water and give a welcome overview of the menu. Noreetuh offers a variety of snacks, starters, and mains, making it an ideal place for shared plates; how else would you try the endless tempting options available?We started first with the Silken Tofu, one of the more visually arresting dishes. Served in a small bowl, the delicate tofu is topped with a few servings of uni (sea urchin), ikura (salmon roe), and a shiitake mushroom duxelle. A few sprigs of shiso finish off the presentation, and it's at once a simple, yet quietly complex dish; the pairing of such ingredients have been tried and true. We also opted for the Corned Beef Tongue Musubi, a take on traditional Hawaiian snack which is usually served with Spam. It was certainly tasty, a foolproof wrapping of sushi rice, cilantro, and crushed peanuts in a nori sheet, and the corned beef a welcome alternative in both taste and texture for the canned "meat product".Perhaps not worth an order are the Kalua Pork Croquettes, two piping hot, deep-fried croquettes served over cabbage with katsu sauce. While tasty, the preparation prevented us from noting any distinction of the kalua. Replace that instead with the much-loved Big-Eye Tuna Poke, a surprisingly traditional take on the popular Hawaiian dish. The tuna is delicious, the subtle flavor highlighted beautifully by the hint of sesame oil and tobanjan-hinted seaweed strands. Let's not forget the addition of the macademia nuts and pickled jalapeño slices, which add just the right amount of heat and acidity to each bite, without overpowering the main protein.For the daring, the Braised Honeycomb Tripe is a solid order. Korean dukbokki, or sticky rice cakes, are cooked with the braised tripe; a smart decision as it takes away the typically overpowering flavor in the offal. Add on a healthy amount of gochujang sauce, the sweet-spicy Korean red pepper paste, and toss with bamboo shoots, onion, and chili, and you have a recipe for success. The bite of my friend's Spam Agnolotti was eye-opening as well, as the pairing with ramps, honshimeji, green almond, and bonito brought out a completely different flavor profile than I had been expecting.I hesitate to call Noreetuh a "fusion" restaurant, as much of Hawaiian cuisine has its roots in Japanese food, and the interplay of Korean ingredients and flavors is smartly and subtly done. What the restaurant has succeeded in doing, however, is establishing an identity that is unique from any other restaurant in the city - which, coupled with well-conceived and executed dishes, makes for a value proposition you can't deny.

I wanted to try Noreetuh when I saw my friend posted pictures of his meal on Facebook soon after it opened.  However, it is always fully booked on Opentable!  I recently checked again, and found a reservation available on 6/25, which coincidentally was the day after the NYT review came out about this place.  Overall impression: Noreeuth was definitely worth the wait!The dishes we tried, ranked from best to mediocre:Octopus poke - I had high expectations for the poke dishes as they were my favorite thing to eat when I was in Hawaii.  This dish was hand's down the best dish of the night.  The tobiko and kimchi provided great complementary textures for the octopus. Moreover, the flavor profile was just amazing, the sauce had the perfect hint of richness that balanced perfectly with the octopus and the spiciness from the kimchiBruleed Hawaiian pineapple - such a simple dish, but so unique and special at the same time.  The brulee crust was perfect and it made that crisp sound when you break into it, and the salt was unexpected, but worked well with the sweetness of the sugar crust and the pineapple.  If anything, I just wish the plate was bigger, for a $10 dish, they can give you half a small pineapple instead of quarter of one.Mochi-crusted halibut - I am normally not a huge fan of fish, but after reading all the reviews on this dish, we decided to give it a try. The mochi-crust was interesting, it does not really taste like mochi, but it provided a nice crunch to the texture.  Moreover, the sauce that accompanied the dish was very delicious, and the pine nuts also gave the dish more depth.Crispy mochi waffles - another dish that had great texture and unusual flavor combination.  I can't believe I never had a mochi waffle before, now I want all of my waffles to be made of mochi.  The combination of whipped peanut butter and honey was heavenly.Corned beef tongue musubi - I couldn't really tell it was beef tongue, I thought it was actually spam for a minute, as it is the traditional meat for a musubi.  The cilantro sauce with crushed peanuts was very tasty, as such, they could've put any meat in there.  Monkfish liver torchon - the toast made from Hawaiian roll elevated the dish, as did the fruit spread underneath the liver.  The monkfish liver was smooth and buttery.Silken tofu - unlike other dishes, I've seen this dish many times in Japanese restaurants, i.e. the combination of uni, ikura and tofu. It was good, but nothing to write home about.Big-eye tune poke - the less interesting of the two poke dishes, it was perfectly fine, but a bit of a let down after trying the octopus poke. It was a bit bland and nothing truly stood out in the dishGarlic shrimp over rice - similar to the tuna poke, this was a decent dish, the shrimp was cooked well, and the pineapple was a good touch. However, garlic shrimp is one of the most popular dishes in Hawaii, particularly among the food trucks in Oahu.  This dish could not hold up in comparison to the amazing ones that were served on the North Shore of Oahu.Service: I can't stop raving about the great service we received.  The waiter was informative, and attentive without being overbearing.  There were three of us, but the musubi dish only had two pieces per order.  He allowed us to order three pieces so that we can have one each.  It was a small gesture, but it made a huge difference.  Overall impression: it was a small restaurant, but they managed to not overcrowd the space with too many tables. I know the NYT review complained about the music, but I hardly noticed any music in the background, the noise level was on par with a small/packed restaurant.  Do note that they don't serve cocktails, only wine and beer.  I would highly recommend the place, and would love to come back to try the other dishes.

We got very excited about this place after the NYT and EaterNY gave it good reviews. Walked in on a Thursday night around 7 and there was a 2 hour wait for a party of 4. Fortunately, there was a last minute cancellation so we were seated after only a 10 minute wait. Service: attentive waiters, cute bartender and very pleasant hostess. Food: everything was just "okay" (1) silken tofu with uni starter was strange tasting. With the texture of silken tofu, I think they need to chill the dish to make it a lot colder. (2) beef tongue musubi - a little tasteless. Kind of like a bad version of stuffed onigiri. (3) kuala pork croquettes: texture was offputting. very crispy bread crumb coating, which was good -- but very mushy pork filling, which was just not appetizing. (4) tuna poke: delicious tasting, but then it's hard to mess up a tuna seafood salad...(5) monkfish liver: the liver was too "processed" - I was expecting cooked monkflish liver on top of some very interesting fruit puree - instead we got on big round peck of compressed puree monkfish liver that tasted part strawberry preserve part fish liver puree. not great. (6) mentaiko spaghetti: oversalted and strangely tasteless. you can barely detect the mentaiko. The dish needs a bit of heat to it too. cracked black pepper or a hint of red pepper would have made it better I think. (7) pineapple braised pork belly: decadent. The pork belly is praised to perfection. but maybe it's the asian in me - felt incomplete without a carb (i.e. rice) to soak up super flavorful and fatty pork belly. overall: great service, nice and clean restaurant. unfortunately, the food was just okay.

Excited to try this new Hawaiian-inspired food and see what it is all about. We even had someone who was a native Hawaiian to chime in with our group.For larger parties, you can make a reservation which was nice for the 7 of us. The wine list was pretty extensive and the waitstaff were good resources to ask about the wines. I ended up also getting a pear cider as they have 4 craft beers and a cider on draught as well.Service was very attentive with two individuals constantly cleaning off tables, giving us fresh plates, refilling our water, and pouring the bottles of wine.We ordered a bunch of dishes, all to share so that we could try everything.SNACKS:We started with the Truffled Taro Chips which was amazing and had so much truffle flavor on each chip.The Corned Beef Tongue Musubi came next and it was wrapped with some flavorless green cilantro sauce and whole peanuts. It was also difficult to keep the rice and peanuts from squishing out after every bite. I secretly wished it was SPAM I was biting into. At least season it... will ya?The Silken Tofu with Uni, Ikura, and Shitake puree was a winner. It was well composed, flavorful, and fresh tasting. STARTERS:The Grass-fed Beef Tartare was boring and bland. You had some small fried greasy wonton chips to put it on. There was this weird light yellow paste on the side that didn't taste like anything either. We did not finish this dish at all.The Octopus Poke was great! The textures were well balanced and the fingerling potatoes gave the dish some depth. The octopus was tender and saltiness of the tobiko brought out the flavors of the sea.The Kalua Pork Croquettes were a miss. It was these fried discs of indeterminate mushy filling inside. The cabbage underneath is just for decoration. The Katsu sauce to dip tasted very generic.The Big Eye Tuna Poke was middle of the road for us. Decently tossed with a variety of seaweed and fresh tasting with the nicely pickled jalapeno but still a bit bland again.The Monkfish Liver Torchon was delightful. It melted in your mouth and the composition of all the flavors worked really well together. It came with mini fluffy white toast.MAINS:The Mentaiko Spaghetti with the butterfish was a good transitional starchy dish that we were craving at this point. It was nicely cooked al dente with a very slight kick to brighten the senses.The Mochi-Crusted Halibut was flaky and nicely seared. I'm not sure where the mochi comes in. It just looked like seared fish with no crust. There was a nice creamy sauce on top with some bok choy on the bottom.The Duck Breast was a let down. We think it was prepared sous vide but was overdone. All the slices were cooked to grey medium well to well done, no pink at all. The apricot kernels that was scattered around didn't work with the dish and the hardness of it was a distractor. The Li Hing Mui is an orange plum that also felt like it was "just there" and didn't cohesively work with the dish.The Pineapple Braised Pork Belly was nice and tender. It was easy to break apart and we all had a taste. The size was very small though and I wouldn't consider it a main.DESSERT:The Bread Pudding was good with golden raisins and pineapple ice cream.The Brûléed Pineapple was a cold quarter chunk of pineapple with a brûléed sugar crust on top dusted with sea salt. Some liked it and half of us didn't. I didn't like how cold it was but the sea salt was a nice touch to bring out the sweetness of the pineapple.Overall, some good dishes while the misses are just because it was boring or wasn't well composed. I guess we had higher expectations going in but while it was generally good, it's nowhere near the top of my list for a place to return to anytime soon. Hopefully, they'll get to work out some of these kinks.

All of the dishes we tried were solid; the heavy hitters include: beef tongue musubi, uni ikura tofu, chow noodles, mentaiko spaghetti, beef tartare, and the monkfish liver.Can't wait to come back and try other dishes. Service was great as well.

Amazing food, great beer and wine selection, excellent service, and a comfortable overall venue - highly recommended. We sat at the bar and ordered half a dozen items along with some beers. The bartender was funny and super nice. Definitely get either the kombu or taro chips (either go great with beer). The crispy mushrooms were decent. The white asparagus was cooked perfectly, and the egg that came with it was really simple but really good. Definitely order the beef tartar - its good on its own but the smoked egg yolk that comes with it really makes the dish stand out. The tuna poke was also a signature dish there - its spicy and super flavorful. If you're in the area, or are craving some good interesting food, definitely give Noreetuh a go.

We had dinner here last night for the first time. Service was very good. The apps and entrees we had were very good too. Wished that they had more non meat entrees on their menu. The wine list was extensive!  The only complaint was that we had a early rez thru opentable. We were hoping for a later evening rez but none were available. But when we got to the restaurant, half the tables were empty during our time there.

This place is amazing !!! We ordered all of the entrees on the menu and three starters.Everything tastes delicious but here are the stand outs:,Pork belly: the pork belly was cooked to perfection with a lovely browning on the fat. I was nervous that it would taste fatty but it just melted in your mouth. The combination of yams and pine nuts in the dish also added a wonderful balance. Halibut: the black bean sauce and bok choy added a meatier taste to the halibut. Also it was cooked to be white and flaky and deliciously meaty. Mentaiko spaghetti: I don't really know how to explain this dish... It has a fishy undertone but looks like spaghetti. The butterfish is slightly smoked and this dish goes great with a rich red wine. This was my favorite dish.. Haha:) The three starters we had were the tuna poke (worth it and delicious) , pork croquette (tuna was better), and the heart of palms salad (the beats in this salad were so flavorful). Desserts: Mochi waffle, pineapple, brownie, and bread pudding. All of them were solid but I especially liked the bread pudding. I will admit that I am biased in general because I do love banana pudding. Overall though I feel like I ate a lot here but at the same time I don't feel completely disgusting. The food is fresh, natural, and light but still filling.

I'm an avid follower of Eater's Heat Maps so naturally, went to Noreetuh within the opening month. Wine list is impressive which isn't a surprise, all the food was unique and pretty solid EXCEPT the pork terrine. We had the pork terrine last so it was a shame, we left our meal on a bad taste. Just checked the menu and it seems they took it off, thank God (goes to show they embrace their name though, right? noreetuh = playground). Wouldn't mind going here if I was in the nabe but wouldn't necessarily make it a point to go here, honestly. All in all, pretty good. Decor is great, clean and modern.

KenScale: 8.0/10Noreetuh (meaning "playground" in Korean) is a new Hawaiian restaurant in East Village from chef Chung Chow, who was sous-chef at the venerable Per Se. You would expect a haute cuisine place from a chef of this pedigree, but what chef Chow is showcasing pays homage to his root from Hawaii, with a lot of Asian elements. I was overall pleased with the playful food offerings from the kitchen.Many of the dishes have inspirations and displays that are fun and employ diverse influences and elements. For snacks, the silken tofu that came with uni, ikura, shiitake and shiso writes Japanese all over its place and was quite pleasant. I was delighted with the way peanuts have been used in some dishes to further enhance the texture. For instances, peanuts worked well together inside the corned beef tongue musubi, as it did for pineapple braised pork belly that came with yams and mustard greens. The pork was cooked quite tender and worked nicely with the crunchy peanuts that, combined with sweet flavor, created a delicious dish. Big-eye tuna poke also came with macadamia nuts, pickled jalapeno and seaweed to create a refreshing starter. The only letdown was the spam agnolotti, which despite the promise of spam, didn't feel as put together as I had hoped. For dessert, bruleed Hawaiian pineapple didn't look like much but provided a refreshing finish to the meal with understated sweet crunch.Getting a reservation doesn't seem particularly difficult, although the restaurant was by no means empty in the course of my meal. I liked the modern, fun vibe of East Village at the dining area. There is no cocktail, but the restaurant has some pretty unique wine selections that are carefully selected by general manager Jin Ahn. I'm by no means an expert to Hawaiian cuisine (until my visit, I really had no idea how to define it), but the food coming out from Noreetuh is fun and worth checking out.

Unique flavors for NYC, but since I'm from the west coast this wasn't spectacular by any means. Again my palate maybe heavily bias as I grew up near many Hawaiian influenced cuisine. The dishes I really wanted to love, but I couldn't. Would give Noteetuh a solid 3.5, great service but lacking in food. Or maybe it was too hyped up? The ingredients are fresh, playing was good.  I thought the pork belly was pretty good, soft and tender.  Wanted to love you Noreetuh.

Dropped by this place w my bestie last week and loved it! Apparently they have only been open for a few months and everything was running very smoothly! This place has a slightly more casual atmosphere but with the service of a classy restaurant! The owner to AGM to our server were so amazing, attentive and polite! Props to them! As for food...my favs were the musubi, the uni tofu (could have probably finished that myself!!), shrimp and the pork belly! Mmmmm....I would recommend this place for a ladies night or date night!!!

Blah The food here is horrible, I looked up some reviews for this restaurant before I go and I'm actually pretty interested in some dishes. And I saw it online it waOrdered taro chips, silken tofu and musubi for the snacks and asparagus for starter pork belly and agnolotti for main. The staff is super friendly and nice. That's why I gave it 3 stars. Otherwise it only deserve 2. Like the taro chips. When I first saw it I was like look at this overpriced chips. But once I had it I just can't stop eating that! really good. The silken tofu with uni and ikura is the worst, I actually was pretty interested in this dish. They didn't clean the sea urchin properly, and still have that weird flavor, which should be rinsed off before they serve it. It just ruin the entire dish. Disgusting. How can you mess up with uni? The asparagus is underwhelming. They served it with chopped egg and Chinese sausage, don't like the green asparagus part, taste kind of bitter. The pork belly is ok, smells delicious just the meat can be more juicy. The agnolotti with spam filling is horrible, they should really learn how to make pasta before put that spam filling inside. The spam filling taste like canned cat food. The overall appearance looks ok when they first come because it was covered with bonito flakes. But the pasta just looks horrible and don't taste good.The server is really nice, we are unhappy with out seat at the first and they switched us to a bigger table immediately. Really touched.

The food was just okay...Tuna poke was very good but nothing special.Pork croquettes were more potato than pork.Garlic shrimp was loaded with garlic and had enough flavor but sat on top of plain white rice with some cold pineapple cubes thrown around the plate.Wagu steak was tasty but came out more steamed than grilled and was a big waste of a really nice cut of meat.Staff was fabulous.  We had a very attentive and helpful server.

The food was okay, but nothing spectacular. The best dishes our group of 5 tried were the tako poke, beef tongue, and chow noodles. The tako poke had a nice creamy texture and crunch. The beef tongue was perfectly cooked and the portions of tongue to rice to seaweed were perfect. The chow noodles had tons of flavor, and lots of mushrooms.  However, I took points off for the ambiance (not a Hawaiian theme, and not really memorable- left something to be desired), no cocktails and small portions (with big dollar signs). Service was impeccable, but seemed too stiff and formal for the tone of the restaurant.

3.5 stars I wanted to like this place but the food was generally very salty. The food seemed very creative and was plated well. Food:Taro chips: okTofu with uni and salmon roe: too salty and the uni was ok qualityBeet and hearts of palm salad: decentMonkfish liver with bite sized toast: very good Mochi encrusted fish: good but a bit heavy Spam tortellini: a bit heavy

For a Hawaiian restaurant, Noreetuh is very simple --  no flashy restaurant sign outside (I don't think they even had a sign), minimalist interior, no gimmicks, no pretentiousness. Noreetuh's focus is the food, the execution, the taste, the creativity, the art... and I really really appreciate that. The menu was inventive and very well planned. All the dishes were beautifully presented and carefully put together. The pineapple braised pork belly was absolutely delicious. The pork belly just melted in my mouth and mixed very well with the sweetness of the pineapple and the texture of peanuts. The imperial wagyu sirloin was pretty much a beef salad but it turned out to be really good as well despite being a very small dish. The meat was cooked just right, the vegetables were fresh, and the dish overall was flavorful. The monkfish liver torchon was amazing. Even the bread that came with it was good. SKIP THE CHIPS. The kombu chips had a unique flavor but it turned out to be a little weird. For dessert, we had the crispy mochi waffles. I love mochi and I really appreciate the inventiveness of Noreetuh's mochi waffle but it just didn't cut it for me. I'm also not a big fan of waffles in general, so there's that too. The food here isn't cheap. Appetizers range from $14-$17 and entrees from $17-$25. The portions were also not the most generous so going for the entree without appetizers would not at all suffice. But again, the food was great and the whole dining experience was warm and refreshing. It was a lovely gastronomical experience and I would happily return for more.

I really, really like this place. Obviously Hawaiian is different and could go gimmicky, but that's not the case here at all. This is a really solid restaurant with great food and terrific wine, and with lovely design and a really warm atmosphere.We loved both our starters - tuna poke is delicious with lots of great texture, and the pork croquettes are great too (not too heavy for a fried food, and the cabbage is just lightly pickled and perfect). My partner really liked the chow noodles for the main, though it's not really my taste. Strangely, I had the pork belly basically because of everything else in the dish (yams, mustard greens, peanuts) - I don't actually like pork belly. But, I loved this dish!!! For dessert, the bread pudding was really good and the macadamia nut brownie with coconut ice cream (with actual coconut flakes) was outstanding.This was a wonderful experience made even better by the friendliness of the servers and the two owners who are out on the restaurant floor.

** 3.5 stars **This intimate, warm restaurant specializes in a rarity in NYC, Hawaiian!  I've yet to visit the Hawaiian islands, and this marks my first visit to any restaurant serving Hawaiian food (although I did sample some from a chicken stand in Portland, Oregon).  Hawaiian food appears to be an amalgam of Asian cuisines, with some interesting ingredients courtesy of its unique locale.  Noreetuh take on this cuisine is elegant and thoughtful.  Take Spam musubi, essentially a jumbo piece of sushi with grilled Spam as the main event.  Noreetuh lets corned beef tongue take over for Spam, with peanuts and cilantro adding texture and depth.  Its fun to eat and tasty, although crispier nori would have made it truly memorable.  Spam finds it way inside silky agnolotti, where its flavor subtly co-mingles with interesting dish mates: seasonal ramps, honshimeji mushrooms, slices of green almonds, and a shower of umami-loaded bonito flakes.  There are two pokes on the menu, a classic raw fish salad.  The big-eye tuna was seasoned and tossed with macadamias, pickled jalapeño, red onions, sesame, and seaweed; there's a lot going on but it works, except for the meaty fish being a touch too sinewy.  More simply satisfying were disks of smooth monkfish liver, contrasting simply with a passionfruit and pear sauce.  Pork belly was decadently tender and fatty, although the pineapple braising that the meat was purported to go through was not notable in its flavor.  The bruleed Hawaiian pineapple from the desserts, however, was a fabulous example of simplicity done right.  A half pineapple was caramelized, seasoned with some lime zest and salt, and served in its half shell.  Perfection, without trying too hard.There is a long, interesting international wine list, and wine pairings are offered with meals.  Other beverages include a few sakes, a premium Korean soju (there is such a thing?), and some draft and bottled beers (sadly, their only Hawaiian offering is no longer available).Noreetuh is cozy but comfortable, with two adjacent narrow dining areas.  It is a step up from casual but not too much.  Service is sweet and attentive.  An error on our bill (not caught by either absent-minded diner) was caught by the manager who phoned expeditiously and corrected it.  For one lacking knowledge of Hawaiian cuisine, Noreetuh still stands out for distinct ingredients and flavors.  There are great aspirations here, which sometimes stumble, but the food remains mostly interesting and fun.  It is a worthwhile experience, and its menu worth exploring again.

My favorite vacation so far was my trip to Hawaii so I was delighted to find a nice Hawaiian food restaurant in NYC.  My dining companion got out early from work so we arrived at 7pm for an 8:15 reservation and they happily seated us.  This starving girl couldn't be more pleased.  Service throughout our meal continued to be cheerful and attentive.Snacks:Truffle taro chips - good with a strong truffle flavor but not a must try in my opinion.Corned beef tongue musubi - interesting with the peanuts inside.  Tasted good but i secretly liked the plain spam ones more though. Starters:Big eye tuna poke - my favorite of the starters.  A good amount of tuna.  It was spicy...not extremely so but just a bit.pork croquettes - fried meat and potatoes...how can you not love it?pork trotter terrine - I didn't like this one.  The best I can describe it is that it was too porky for me and the sauce that came with it didn't improve the flavor for me.Mains:Garlic shrimp over rice - The garlic shrimp trucks in Hawaii were heaven so I couldn't pass this up.  Pretty presentation but sadly it couldn't compare to the flavor from the authentic Hawaiian trucks and didn't really satisfy my craving. Pineapple braised pork belly - get this.  That is all I have to say about this dish.  It was tender flavorful (perhaps a bit on the salty side) and delicious.The two of us were too full after all the food we ordered above to fit dessert.  Maybe next time.  (Although we cleared the little wooden container of gummy candy in seconds........it was there...no sense in resisting.)

It seems like every 10-15 places we pick from via Yelp rankings are completely off and it usually happens with those places with not that many reviews.We are still scratching our heads as to how this place warranted 4-5 stars and we suspect this one will settle out somewhere around 3-4 over time.It seemed like none of the dishes we tried had any real backbone/character/aggression and were noncommittal in flavor.  And we were absolutely famished we walked in and were in the mood to try anything - we did not ask the server any questions and just picked shit at random.  Turns out we had the corned beef tongue musubi which was probably the highlight and the most richly-flavored item, but it went all sideways from there as the hearts of palm, the white asparagus and the mains of chow noodles and mentaiko spaghetti just got shrugs around our table.We walked in with enthusiasm and walked out deflated - and the most novel part of the dinner was the sign on the single toilet for the restaurant.  Decor was slick and the service was impeccable but those factors will not be enough to get us back thru the door...

Also blown away!  Hubby had 2x glasses of chardonnay (blech), I had some sake, we got the tuna poke app (delicious), the asparagus app (also really nice + fresh), I got the shrimp main (could eat that every night for dinner!!  it's a zen master of simplicity) and hubby got the fluke.We are kind of dabbling in low-carb healthy eating, so that's why we stuck to the healthy stuff.  They have a fried mushroom app that looks amazing, same with dessert...  We will try next time.Mahalo and welcome to the neighborhood!

I found a very high grade service and high quality menus in east village.I have been looking for a place to hang out late night in east village, finally I found the one. They just opened tow months ago, but they'll all professionals. They are very casual style, but they know all the fundamentals for service.  Bartender was nice and knowledgeable, no time to feel alone. Server and GM were super-super-professional. I wish they opened till midnight for a while....

I don't like Spam. Sometimes living with someone who likes those cans of pre-cooked meat can be tough. Whenever I see a Spam can blankly blinking back at me from our kitchen counter, I internally scream and push it into one of the cabinets. If I get asked a, "Wait, where did the Spam go?" I usually respond with an innocent-looking shrug and a surge in interest in whatever I happen to be doing at the time. So, I was reluctant to come here because my narrow-mindedness made me just assume that Hawaiian-inspired food would mean a lot of Spam dishes. Well, I'm here to tell you that I liked it. I'm also here to tell you that there was only one Spam dish on the menu. Hawaiian food is so much more than Spam!! A lot of the dishes here were influenced by Japanese, Korean, and Filipino cuisines, and everything we tasted was fresh and balanced. Yum. Plates were on the smaller side, but we left pretty stuffed after a snack each, a starter to share, an entree each, and a dessert to share.  -corned beef tongue musubi with cilantro and peanuts: This was their take on the classic spam musubi. The glaze was the perfect level of sweetness and the beef tongue incredibly tender. I loved the bits of peanuts in this! It really added dimension; each bite was satisfying.  -spicy gobo with wood ear mushroom and bellflower root: I was looking forward to this dish since I assumed it'd be similar to kinpira gobo (braised burdock) which I love. Unfortunately, it was a little too sweet for me and was eerily similar to the taste of seaweed salad. It wasn't the slightest bit spicy and this is coming from someone who cannot tolerate spice! The gobo was also cut into long thin shreds, and eating it from a bowl with forks was messy and unsuccessful, so chopsticks would have been appreciated.  -big-eye tuna poke with macadamia nuts, pickled jalapeño, and seaweed: Delicious! This was a well-balanced medley of ingredients that was texturally interesting, and was by consequence very beautiful and vibrant. It also didn't leave me wanting rice. The tuna was fresh and its natural taste was maintained. -chow noodles with morels, asparagus, pea tendrils: This dish confirmed the chefs' interest in using the freshest ingredients while being mindful of texture. These chow noodles, thankfully, were presented with chopsticks by their side. A decent portion of wide noodles were tossed with a heavy dose of sesame oil and soy sauce, and then combined with fantastic bites of ridgy morels, tender asparagus, and crunchy pea tendrils.  -spam agnolotti with ramps, honshimeji, green almond, bonito flakes: The dancing bonito flakes were a curious addition, but ended up being a good one because the agnolotti was surprisingly as sweet as squash (even almost had that consistency), and I was surprised at myself for liking it so much.   -king's hawaiian bread pudding with rum raisins, pineapple ice cream: Fantastic.Wine pairings started at $35 and corkage fees were $15. Wines were sold by the glass at very reasonable prices. The list was short, but a variety of types and regions were covered. Along with sake and soju, there were also draft beers and bottles. The Badass Quite a Pear hard cider was phenomenal, by the way.Likelihood of another visit:This casual, cozy restaurant had such warm service and delicious food! They also gave us Japanese gummies with our check. I'd love to come back to try almost everything I ate here.

SALT. If you come here, hope you like to eat excessive amounts of salt. 90% of the food was way too salty for the average person. Nothing special about the apps (we ordered all of them). The croquettes lacked flavor and were a bit deflated. The tuna poke was great and a must order if you go. Garlic shrimp was good. Large, plump shrimps. It's a very simple dish though and certainly doesn't garner the price tag...served with white rice, fresh pineapple, and raw romaine lettuce. The noodles were excessively salty. Couldn't taste anything else. Avoid all the apps and most of the starters except for the poke. Stick to the mains. Our service was pushy and smothering. It's a small space so it constantly felt like she was hovering over us.Also, noise absorbing panels would be a good investment. The echo and din is very high here.

I was sooo excited to see that there is a Hawaiian restaurant in NYC!  When you go, it is a spin off using Hawaiian classic ingredients.  The food is amazing, I feel like we tried everything on the menu, the space is simple and cozy (not tacky with tiki decor), the staff was very helpful and knowledgable. I'm going back very soon!  Just go!!

A welcome addition to the neighborhood and worthy of being a destination spot for everyone else! Noreetuh has already achieved the restaurant trifecta--delicious and innovative food, friendly and attentive service, elegant yet casual and fun atmosphere. And of course an amazing and well priced wine list! Just hope it doesn't get too crowded so we can go regularly without having to make reservations months in advance...

Noreetuh is the newest hot Hawaiian spot that opened in East Village by former Per Se alums. The restaurant was surprisingly small, seating probably only 20 people at best, so I would definitely recommend making a reservation.The menu is only 1 page long, so 3 of us were able to try nearly half the menu.Appetizers:- truffle taro chips- pork trotter terrine- pork Katsu croquettes- tuna pokeMains:- wagyu short rib- honeycomb tripe- pork bellyEverything was delicious, and I appreciated the fact that despite ordering a lot of meat, each dish was well balanced so the meal never felt too heavy or greasy.  The portions aren't ridiculous, stuff-your-face-sized, but I thought the standard 1 app and 1 entree per person was the perfect amount of food.Sadly I thought dessert fell a little short compared to the rest of the menu (and I have a huge sweet tooth). The mochi waffles with peanut butter was extremely dry and the Hawaiian bread pudding was a little too soggy and sweet for my taste (though as a disclaimer I don't really like bread pudding in general).

I had a great meal here last night. Every dish tasted very fresh, and bursting with flavor. I especially loved the hearts of palm! The atmosphere was also very nice (especially loved the music) and the service was very professional. I will definitely be coming back here again

There is rarely a time when I walk away from a meal feeling like it was a waste of money but that's how I felt after having dinner here. My friend and I were only able to get a reservation at 6:15 on Thurs. Not sure why considering half the tables were empty while we were dining and by the time we were done only one table was occupied. The food is good but not sure it's worth it. $10 for taro chips and the pineapple brulee is receiving way too much press. Again for $10 I felt like it was something I could have made at home. I enjoyed the ahi tuna starter dish the most. Also the food came out so fast, unnecessarily fast.

this new hawaiian place blew us away! we have wandered past a few times but never stopped to look at the menu, finally stopped in for dinner and ..WOWthe food is fresh, super flavorful, and we loved the perfectly sized portions.  we had the Silken Tofu (hands down my favorite ever, the mushrooms just give it such dimension!) the Poke (delicious, lovely bit of heat from pepper but balanced with cooling seaweed), the Fluke (SO good, crispy not greasy, and the sauce is delicious), the noodle bowl (again, lovely balanced flavor and not salty) and the Monkfish liver (this was our dessert- we loved the fatty fish liver beautifully balanced with the passionfruit)we dont feel at all that the portions were "meager", we were very satisfied and loved that we were able to eat a few items without walking out feeling stuffed.i am a fish eating vegetarian, so didn't try the beef tongue, but my husband had it an loved them!all of this amazing food was complemented with great service. we ate at the bar and the bartender Benjamin was so helpful and attentive-- we got great menu advice, as well as enjoying an array of sake & beers to suit each course. definitely sit at the bar and get his take on things if you are new to this type of foodwe felt the overall price of our dinner was actually a bargain considering how many mediocre places around charge more for a pile of slop.. we loved the high quality ingredients you could really taste, the truly excellent service, and how satisfied our palattes and our bellies were as we walked homeHIGHLY recommend this place!

Came in on the late-ish side on a Thursday night and was immediately seated at a bar table. Ordered a sizeable amount from the menu - tongue musubi, spicy gobo, taro chips, poke, spam agnolotti, and mochi crusted fluke. The standouts were definitely the musubi and agnolotti. I could have eaten multiple orders of the agnolotti - tender tasty and most fancy way I've ever had spam. Portions were on the meager side - but's great to have quality over quantity and not leave a meal feeling like there's a bowling ball of spam in my stomach.

This new Hawaiian restaurant is quite impressive. The three founding chefs all met each other while working at Per Se, so you know that they know how to put good food on a plate. The dishes here are simple, yet elegant and delicious. The menu is very affordable with no dish over $22. Portions are a bit on the small side, so I'd advise getting an appetizer to share along with your main.We got the corned beef tongue musubi which is a glammed-up version of spam musubi - a Hawaiian staple. Next we got the big-eye tuna poke seaweed salad. I highly recommend this - the flavors meld together well and everything on the plate is very fresh. I think it's one of the most popular starters on the menu.For our mains we got the mochi-crusted fluke and the chow noodles. The chow noodles are quite spicy, so if you don't care for spice beware. I love spicy food and really enjoyed it. The mochi-crusted fluke was pretty bomb - my only complaint is I wish there were more.Check this place out before it becomes too popular! I wouldn't be surprised if Noreetuh earned a michelin star one day.

Went here one night and it was definitely different.The food I ordered were Silken Tofu, Fried Mushrooms, Tuna Poke, and the Beef Tripe rice cake.  For a restaurant that suppose to have 3 per se alums i was expecting this to be amazing, but it was just ok.  The silken tofu was different taste than what I was use to, but it didn't make me want more of it.  Maybe I am not use to the taste.The Fried Mushrooms was probably the one i liked the most out of all the dish.  However, I feel this was something that anyone could make by just putting it in batter and frying it.Tuna poke was good, but nothing special.Beef tripe rice cake was also good, but nothing special.  I was hesitant about trying it since i read a review that this tasted like gasoline.Overall, this place was just ok. I didn't feel I walked out of there with a wow factor and feel me wanting to come back to try it again.  Service was pretty good and the servers were tentative.

Food is fine. Nothing worth going back for. We tried: beef tongue, truffle chips, tuna poke, ravioli, fish, noodles, garlic shrimp. I think the only really good dish was the tuna poke, but that's a tough dish to mess up.Overall, a 'meh'.

I'm shocked by the current 4.5 overall score for Noreetuh. We had dinner there tonight and thought it was just okay.First, the actual space of the restaurant is truly awkward. It is cramped and very narrow and hardly decorated. It felt like little effort had been put into the appearance, which was strange. I must say that it also didn't help that a baby was screaming for quite awhile a few tables away. I absolutely understand that sometimes nothing can be done and I feel for the parents but this went on for so long that it significantly diminished the dining experience.The service was good. The food was mixed. I will break it down by what we ordered.1. The silken tofu. This was nice, as I love both uni and fish eggs. The mushroom tapenade that came with it was excellent and so flavorful. 4 stars.2. The tuna poke. This was my favorite of the night. Fresh delicious cubes of tuna mixed with seaweed, macadamia nuts and some fantastic pickled jalapeños. 5 stars.3. The mochi-crusted fluke entree was disappointing. The whole dish was bland, the portion was small and the fish was overcooked. 1.5 stars.4. The spam tortellini entree was much better than the fish entree. The spam filling was salty and flavorful and mixed nicely with the runny egg yolk. It was overall an odd dish, though, with the goji berries. Interesting but strange. 3.5 stars.5. The pineapple dessert was nice. I've never had a brûléed pineapple before so it was a treat. 4 stars.Overall, I don't understand what the hype is all about. Dinner at Noreetuh was fine but I'm not dying to return. The prices were also HIGH.

One of my most favorite eating trips ever was a two week vacation in Hawaii, so I am always excited to try a new Hawaiian restaurant in NYC, especially since they are relatively rare here. One of the things I loved about the food there was how satisfying it was, but this meal just left me wanting more.It is easy to see that this intimate new spot is run by former Per Se chefs, as the portions are on the small side and the prices are on the high side. There are a good number of choices on the menu, most of which have some type of interesting Hawaiian influence:- Truffle Taro Chips ($11)These were pretty delicious and a nice way to start the meal. As just mentioned though, this was a little bowl for $11. I wouldn't mind less truffle and getting some complimentary chips to start instead.- Corned Beef Tongue Musubi, Cilantro, Peanut ($6)This was one of my favorites, swapping out the typical spam for some delicious tongue. This was one of the few items that was very reminiscent of the stuff I tried in Hawaii and was done exceptionally well.- Silken Tofu, Uni, Ikura, Mushroom, Shiso ($12)I'm not a big uni guy, but if you like it, chances are you also like ikura, and furthermore silken tofu, so you will probably be in heaven with this dish. The textures were just way too mushy for me to enjoy, but you should kind of expect that going in knowing the ingredients here.- Big-Eye Tuna Poke, Macadamia Nuts, Pickled Jalapeno, Seaweed ($17)This was ok. It was a little too light on the tuna though, dominated mostly by the pickled jalapeno and seaweed.- Kalua Pork Croquettes, Cabbage, Katsu Sauce ($11)These were two large discs of kalua pork encased in a crispy, fried batter, and of course very delicious. Other than the musubi, this was definitely the best bite of the meal.- Chow Noodles, Bean Sprouts, Jalapeno, Shiitake, Lily Flower, Spiced Tofu ($16)These were pretty good, but I would have loved some meat in here. Also, it was a tiny bowl of noodles that I couldn't help but notice was smaller than the size of half of the portion you get with the stellar peanut noodles at Tuome with the Pig Out feast,.- Spam Tortellini, Poached Egg, Yu Choy, Goji Berries, Chrysanthemum ($17)This one was just not good. The Tortellini seemed extremely undercooked, as each piece took work to chew through.- Macadamia Nut Brownie, Coconut Ice Cream ($9)This brownie was pretty good, but not $9 good. I believe the ice cream was from Davey's, so instead of ordering this here, go across the street to Davey's to get an even bigger, better scoop, with an excellent brownie as well if you wish.- Crispy Mochi Waffles, Whipped Peanut Butter, Alaea Salt ($8)This was actually incredible, mostly because I am a major peanut butter guy. The peanut butter on top of the light waffles was super rich and creamy, and paired with that hint of salt and the crispiness of the waffles, it was a perfect bite. Make sure you get this dessert.Overall, the meal was enjoyable. The ambiance is really nice and laid-back and the service was perfect. The food just didn't really live up to expectations and it was a little too pricey to justify and didn't wow enough to warrant a return visit.

Outstanding! Don't know that I've had Hawaiian in New York City, and this was a great addition.We started with the poke tuna which was perfectly seasoned, and the Kalua pork  croquettes were just the right amount of salty -- I've had some Kalua pork that way over-does it.The pork belly was wonderfully fatty and cooked just right, and the garlic shrimp tasted just like the food truck on the north coast of Oahu!

My 4 star review is more 3&1/2, but Noreetuh has the potential to be great. The six of us dined here in late March. We were very excited for some "local" style Hawaii cuisine. The dishes were creative and interesting. Our main gripe was with service. Our server had to check with a manager or the chef about 4-5 times to clarify or get approval for things (we inquired with what the family style service was --assuming it was larger portions to share with the table, but it wasn't really). He had a difficult time explaining our options. Yes, we know they had recently opened and were still getting the kinks out. But I thought our questions weren't out of the ordinary. With all that said and done we ordered and got the food we wanted. For starters we shared the beef tongue musubi (interesting spin), silken tofu, poke (tasty), and kalua pork croquettes (my favorite). Then my husband and I shared the garlic shrimp rice (I thought was delicious and flavorful) and mochi crusted fluke (nothing too exciting). Then for desserts we had the bruleed pineapple (simple, great presentation, my favorite), macadamia brownie (condensed and hard to share), and the mochi waffles (simple and interesting).

Noreetuh is a nice welcome to the E Village. The staff is really friendly and accommodating. We came with an infant and they gave us a corner booth that they could have used to seat 4. Food is original and interesting - and we love the touch of Korean / Japanese in menu. Great experience overall.

Really great dining experience.  The staff was extremely friendly and created a very nice atmosphere.We started with the truffle chips and poke, both were excellent, especially the poke which is better than a lot of the poke I've had in Hawaii.  Then we had the steak and fluke, both delicious and really well done.  Then the pineapple for desert which was a perfect finish to the meal.I will definitely be coming back here.

I can't say I'm completely thrilled about Noreetuh even if it was opened by three per-se alum. I was really hoping that they would take me back to my trip to Hawaii.Came here for dinner on a Wednesday night and the restaurant is definitely small. Luckily it wasn't crowded when we arrived at 7pm which confused me because according to OpenTable, the restaurant was booked solid till 10pm -- weird!Either case, the service was very high end and you do feel a sense of sophistication. Our server was delightful and attentive. However I can't say the same for the food.We ordered their truffled taro chips and it was somewhat boring. I get that the taro chips had sprinkled black truffles on top but for me it's pointless if you can't taste it.As for their spicy gobo, I thought it was good but being categorized as a snack instead of a side dish didn't make sense, especially if eaten independently on its own.We also ordered their silken tofu and visually it was beautiful and artfully put together but taste wise, it was bland and sparing. The only thing I really enjoyed were the three uni. As for the silken tofu, I think it's only about half an inch high, which is practically nothing if served in a small bowl that is about the size of my palm.The corned beef tongue musubi was okay. It wasn't packed tightly so the rice kept on falling out and the peanut with cilantro paste was bland and didn't add any additional flavor to the beef tongue or the rice.As for the big eyed tuna, I thought it was good but it's not something I care to order again. I had the same dish when I was in Hawaii at a supermarket and even that being prepared there tasted better. Perhaps quality wise, Noreetuh will surpass a supermarket but taste-wise it failed.Lastly we had their braised honeycomb tripe and I felt the dish was too saucy and salty. As a result, I couldn't really taste the tripe nor the rice cake. Instead the dish just tasted like one big flavor instead of multiple flavors being put together as one.Overall, I wish this restaurant luck but unfortunately I feel they did not deliver the Hawaiian taste that I was expecting.
Very flavorful interesting combinations, some work better than others.Big fan of the flatiron steak with miso based sauce
