Food and people here are what make it at this casual Hawaiian inspired restaurant.Atmosphere is good with a great playlist and simple décor that keeps you focused on the quality of service and food. Great hospitality at play. The food is some of the better modern Hawaiian you will find outside of the islands; you see influence from Japanese, Filipino and Korean cuisine - just like the food in Hawaii. Wine list focuses on French selections a deeply discounted prices. Saw Volnay d'angerville for $95. Not just a really great bargain but a very hard wine to find in general. Kudos for curating such a great list! There's a wine pairing option for $35 that I would like to try next visit.Tried the fried mushrooms, taro chips, kombu chips, tuna poke, Kalua pork croquettes, chow noodles, king Hawaiian bread pudding and the brulee Hawaiian pineapple.  Everything was well made and presented beautifully. The chow noodles are made in house and wow. This is the one dish to not miss. Definitely a must try. The combination of the noodles with tofu and mushrooms was incredible. This dish disappeared far too fast. Need to come back to get more chow noodles as well as try the spam tortellini and silken tofu.If you are looking for flavorful food from the islands in a nice atmosphere with good wine and great hospitality, this is the spot for you.
Great atmosphere and staff! The food is delicious especially the taro chips and the noodles. I would definitely come back here!

A SPOT THAT CAN FINALLY SATIATE MY HAWAIIAN FOOD WITHDRAWALS?! IT'S A DREAM COME TRUE!I dined at this small, East Village joint with two other girlfriends to wind/wine down, snack on some Hawaiian treats and catch up.We ordered the following:1. Truffled Taro Chips2. Big Eyed Tuna Poke - tasted great with the above! 3. Garlic shrimp - mouthwatering morsels of garlicky goodness!Overall, wonderful food with great flavors and presentation but way overpriced for the portion size. The great appeal about poke, spam musubis and other Hawaiian delicacies is it's good food for good prices. Noreetuh definitely has good food for not so good prices.

The food and people here are absolutely incredible!!I started off with the truffled taro chip, mushrooms, and the uni dish. I will be back for the kombu chips!!!The fried mushrooms were absolutely amazing.... So light, airy, crispy.... They are to die for! I could snack on the taro chips all day. I hope they start selling bags to go! :)My absolute favorite was the mochi fluke! It was perfection and together with that yam it was heaven.And the drinks there? So many options to choose from. Best wine list ever!I hear the owners are super handsome too :)

Decent food, but felt mostly like decent Asian food that just cost a bit more.We stopped by as a group of 4 for dinner on a Saturday, but it took a while to get seated given how busy it was; we eventually got seated within an hour but had to sit at the bar. For starters, we split the corned beef tongue musubi, the big eye tuna poke, kalua pork croquettes, and the pork trotter terrine. The musubi was quite good, but everything else was just decent. The pork croquettes were decent and tasty but fairly ordinary, and the tuna poke was similar as in it was mostly tuna mixed with other stuff. For entrees, we split the braised honeycomb tripe, pineapple braised pork belly, mochi-crusted fluke, and the spam tortelloni. My favorite was the tripe with rice cakes, but it was unfortunately rice cake and didn't have enough tripe and a bit overwhelmed by the chili. The mochi on the fluke was entirely imperceptible, and the dishes in general were just nice and fairly ordinary. The service overall was nice, and they were very helpful with recommending dishes and soliciting feedback. I'd consider coming back at some point, but as it stands, the dishes were fairly generic, although a bit cleaner in flavor and well presented, but just a bit on the expensive end for that quality.

Though there are many new restaurants in the EV, Noreetuh is the best new restaurant we have tried in a while. The decor is modern-minimalist but not bare; had a cozy neighborhood feel. The host was accommodating and welcoming. We did not have a reservation, but gladly sat at the wine, beer, and most importantly, sake bar.  The bartender was equally as familiar with the drinks as with the food. We ordered the recommended spicy gobo snack, which was refreshing, slightly spicy, and delicious; followed by the fresh big-eye tuna poke containing complementary flavors.  Slightly less healthy (but amazing) were the kalua pork croquettes, a take on a a Spanish tapa with katsu sauce.  For entrees, I had the pineapple braised pork belly and my fiancée had the fluke.  We would order both again. We finished with the brownie, comfort desert      made special by the accompanying coconut ice cream with sea salt. We would absolutely go back and recommend highly!

Brilliant. Every flavor was a perfect note in a melody of food. We started with the truffle taro chips and silken tofu, which was silky and delicious.  We followed with the monkfish torchon, which was accompanied with Hawaiian bread, and the hearts of palm - the flavors of the monkfish were well completed by the sweetness of the passion fruit, and hearts of palm salad made me smile. The combination of the shallots and cilantro left a taste that was unique and memorable but not cloying. On to the entrees - mochi-crusted fluke was expertly prepared and the bok choy added a really nice texture to the fish, and a nice counter to the sweetness of the kabocha squash. Chow noodles? Yum.  Just, yum.  Eat them up. Everything was served in a timely manner and for a new restaurant, no "oopses" like rapid or slow courses, or an entree showing up before the app. I really can't wait to go back - i usually don't try to be an armchair food writer, but this place was pretty darn awesome.
Can't complain.  Nice ambiance and good service.  The food was definitely different.   Their wine list is pretty extensive.

This place is going to blow it up once the word gets out. The food and service here are first class. The menu is well thought out and executed with perfection.  For the prices they're charging, it's a steal. No seriously, a steal.  You're getting Michelin quality food and service at an obscenely low price. If I lived closer, I would eat here every day. Bravo Noreetuh team! Well done!

The only words I can use to describe noreetuh are with adjectives- pretty adjectives: woodsy, oceany seawater, smokey, umami, chewy, comforting. After food gawking from a Gothamist article about noreetuh, I somehow made the decision that I HAD to get there before it blows up. Plus they had poke! Including some truffle & sea urchin on the menu, thought it was all an interesting mix, super excited that they have a "Hawaiian-inspired" menu. Noreetuh takes reservations, but it seems to have been very busy since opening. For a table, I'd say you'll need to book 1-2wks in advance. They have 6 bar stools for walk-ins. The Boy and I went at 6:30 on a Wednesday, zero wait and got a cozy spot at the front section of the bar. The front door host was extremely nice and the staff was Very attentive all night; making sure water glasses were filled & plates coming out in perfect timing. The restaurant itself is very small, holding exactly two tables for 2, two for 4, one large table for 4-5, and a round large booth in the back room (seemed like the guests at the back table were regualrs). Even though seating is limited, it has a nice relaxed feel though, you don't feel cramped, and the lighting and industrial minimal wood dark gray design creates a warm & cool atmosphere, if that makes sense. They turned up the 80's R&B later in the night (MJ & Monica!). Large single bathroom too. A guy that looked like one of the Owner's brother came in and his brother pulled a stool up to the bar for him, for a glass of cider and app. The was another diner there that had a 'famous' aura to him, dining at a large table, looked a little like Adrien Brody, but with light brown man bun well-conditioned curls. Can't put my finger on him.. The food: total about $95$12 Glass of red wine, soucherie$12 Silken Tofu, Uni (sea urchin), Ikura (Salmon Roe), Shitake paste, shiso leaves: seawater meets the woods. umami. I didn't know what to expect, but it was a great combination of the creaminess of the tofu (about an 1" deep), salt of the Uni & broth/soy on top, bright bursts of the roe, and a little kick of shiso. I do wish there was a little more light to see what we were eating, asked the bartender what the brown paste was. It was like the most dense mushrooms compote you'll ever eat. Nice contrast. Highly recommend.$11 Truffle Taro Chips: salty paper thin taro chips with black truffle shavings. I tasted more salt than truffle, but then I'm not exactly versed in truffle flavor. The Boy said that it's mild, like an aromatic vanilla after taste. He approved.$17 Big-eye tuna poke, mac nuts, jalapeño, seaweed, red onion: decent portion for poke. I could only eat half of it- too much rawness for me- perfect to share, but the tuna cubes were extra fresh- didn't taste too much marinade after the first bite (sesame oil drizzle used?) I think the jalapeño and bits of red onion made up for it, but after a while the heat from the jalapeño took over. We cut up the large bits of yellow seaweed, it provided a nice textural contrast. Were there some fennel leaves in there? It was good but I probably wouldn't get this again as the jalapeño was overpowering in the end.$17 Spam tortellini, poached egg, Chinese broccoli rabe, goji berries, white slightly bitter aerated cream sauce: excellent & inventive. Warm and comforting. The tortellini was fresh & were handmade little puffs of cheese & spam purée with a few larger pieces of spam. The pasta noodle part was chewy and hearty. I only got to only try a bite of this main since it wasn't mine, but it looked great- breaking the egg & mixing it in a little and the touch of chinese greens also.$16 Chow noodles, shitake, smoked tofu, jalapeño, broiled lily flower, bean sprouts, cilantro, scallion: Smokey. That's what I got from it. The handmade noodles were hearty and had a nice chew. I'm not quite sure if I listed all of the ingredients in this dish- there were so many contrasting, yet hearty flavors. I wanted to lay them out separately on the dish & take a pic, but that would be Way too Yelp of me for the Boy. The broiled lily flowers were a nice surprise and gave a sort of bamboo shoot like texture. Generous amounts of shitake and tofu. The tofu wasn't that gross dried smoked tofu that you find tossed upon the tops of $3 noodles, it was moist, flexible as the shitake, but meatier. I'm guessing made in house or from a high quality place. This dish seemed very Malaysian or Chinese inspired. Overall, a nice fancee but casual dining experience. Slightly high for my price range, but the main dishes where definitely worth it. The overall quality shows in the food & execution. Good luck to the chefs and owners!PS. Not sure if they added to the decor because of a Yelper's comment. But not a fan of the laser-printed canvases that they had up. Dumbs it down. Stay with the natural minimal themes please! Maybe a honeycomb wood panels, small ceramic objects, or little flat versions of your gold pineapple.

Amazing food and wine. All of the dishes were exquisitely crafted with finesse and care. The service was attentive and unobtrusive. The atmosphere is casual/modern. The experienced staff are knowledgeable and truly professional. Our party had a great dinner. I truly believe they will only get better with time. I will definitely come again. Bravo Noreetuh!

Very excited for this place to open since there are not many restaurants in nyc that serve anything resembling hawaiian food. This restaurant elevates hawaiian comfort food, which is expected since the team behind it have some impressive past projects. That being said, expect the usual high price tag and small portion sizes that comes with the increased level of sophistication. Overall the food was excellent and the staff was wonderfully warm, attentive and courteous.  There was a $15 corkage fee which is extremely reasonable, but maybe we'll try some of their wine pairings next time. As starters we ordered the poke, musubi, croquette and pork terrine. The poke was great, very silky cubes of tuna with excellent flavors. The seaweed was fresh and crunchy but I wish the ratio of fish to seaweed was a little higher. I also thought the nuts should have been served finer (they were a little overpowering being as large as they were-practically whole). We would have ordered 3 more and one to go if the price tag was anything like poke bowls in Hawaii. We LOVED the beef tongue musubi. Simple as that. The kalua pork croquette was good, but to me the flavor came from the dipping sauce, not enough from the smokiness of the pork. The pork terrine was liked by the other people at the table but I was neutral. For entrees we ordered the pork belly, spam torteloni and garlic shrimp. The shrimp were as delicious as expected. Like a north shore shrimp truck but x3 the cost :) Ours were fresh and they got the garlic spot on (not overpowering). I'd pass on the spam torteloni... It was very rich and salty but the flavor was somewhat bland (and the spam taste really did not come through). The pork belly was wonderfully tender and the sauce was excellent. We split a macnut brownie with coconut ice cream for dessert. It was as straightforwardly delicious as it sounds (but maybe we'll get a little braver and try something more inventive next time). We're excited to go back and try the items we missed :) Keep it up Noreetuh!

Hawaiian food with a Hawaiian! I've been to Honolulu and loveddd the food so I was excited to try this. Opened by 3 Per Se alum's? It has to be amazing, right? WRONG.I would only recommend the following- Corned beef tongue musubi- Silken tofu: All the flavors came together very well and it's also hard to mess up uni- Tuna poke: The texture of the seaweed, fish and heat of the jalalpeno really came together. - King's Hawaiian bread puddingUnfortunately the rest of the meal wasn't as outstanding- Kalua pork croquettes: Not much flavor without the dipping sauce- Garlic shrimp over rice: The shrimp came out luke warm and there wasn't much flavor. The Hawaiian said he could cook better garlic shrimp- Braised honeycomb tripe: This was by far the worst dish. We took one bite of the rice cake which was was hard and tasted of gas. The first dish I have ever sent back in a restaurant. - Crispy mochi waffles: The idea of it sounds great but the execution was disappointing. It tasted like hard stale bread with peanut butter and drizzled with honey.They offer wine parings starting at $35 for 3 glasses. We were served champagne and two whites. They are light with the pours, I would recommend getting a bottle of wine instead. I really wanted to like you Noreetuh but everything fell short of expectations. The portions were small and the meal was not worth $200+. There are too many restaurants in NYC to come back here again. Realistically 2 stars, bumped up a star for attentive service.

This rating is really closer to a 3.5 but yelp won't allow for it.  I really wanted to love this place because it's so hard to find quality Hawaiian or Hawaiian-inspired food here in NYC.  I was so excited to try this place that I made a reservation pretty much as soon as I heard about it opening.  Unfortunately, I was disappointed by our experience here.  We ordered the silken tofu with uni, the ahi poke and two orders of the garlic shrimp and rice plate.  The uni and tofu was a surprisingly delicious combination, and I would recommend this as a starter.  Even better was the ahi poke with a few different types of seaweed and a kick from some pickled jalapeño.  Sadly, the positives end there.  Our waitress was very sweet and attentive.  Trouble was that we waited for a long time between each course.  We probably waited about 30 mins for our poke and another 40 for our entree.  By the time we got our shrimp dishes, we were thrilled to be digging into our dish.  First, we were really sad to find that the shrimp was inexplicably lukewarm in temperature - definitely not hot.  Had it been sitting in the window all this time?  We couldn't figure it out.  It was also under-seasoned (needed more salt).  I wanted to bring the temperature issue to our waitress, but then decided it wasn't worth it to wait another 30 minutes for another dish.  We continued to eat.  A couple of shrimp in, I discovered that the shrimp wasn't fully cooked.  There were parts of some shrimp that were still rubbery and translucent.  I couldn't excuse this too.  I finally waived down the waitress and expressed my disappointment.  She apologized and I asked if I could order a different dish.  She allowed me to do so.  I ordered the pork belly instead.   In the meantime, my fiancé continued to eat his shrimp and later discovered that some of his shrimp were also not fully cooked.  He just ate around it.  To their credit, the pork belly came out pretty quickly and the manager said that he hoped this dish would work out better for me.  However, he didn't apologize for the shrimp being undercooked and cold, and I interpreted his comment and failure to apologize like the shrimp was just not to my taste.  I wasn't aware that the dish I orderedwould come undercooked... Anyway, they did remove one of the shrimp entrees from our bill (but still charged us for the new dish).  The pork belly was much better:  tender, flavorful and this time, fully cooked!Overall, I wish I could praise this restaurant but I just didn't have a great experience there today.  I know they recently opened, so perhaps they need some time to work out the kinks.  But shrimp is pretty simple to cook, and I would hope that former Per Se chefs should know how to cook shrimp properly.  Long story short, I'm sad to say that I will not be rushing back to this restaurant.

Sometimes, there are certain things about a restaurant that stand out- the decor, the service, the food, etc. For me, at Noreetuh, it was the music. I am completely unashamed to admit that I was happy to hear Nick Jonas' "Chains" playing softly in the background.While the music was exciting and unexpected, the restaurant itself was pretty bare bones. No art on the wall, no photos, no color, nothing. Perhaps, they're going for the "minimalist" approach.  The restaurant is very small. It can probably serve about 20-25 people, that's including the bar area. This accounts for the 30+ min wait I had for a seat. I did notice that there is a separate "private dining room" in the back, which can probably fit a few more guests. The food is very flavorful and light and each dish looks like it's carefully composed on the plate. The only problem was with the speed [or there lack of] in which it came from the kitchen. There is no cocktail list, just wine.__Food:Silken Tofu [$12]: I told the server that this dish tasted like the ocean. I was not kidding. The uni was exceptionally fresh and briny and the fish roe burst in your mouth. This was the perfect starter, in size and in taste. Pork Trotter Terrine [$12]: Curiously, I was expecting more of a traditional presentation rather than what resembled a crudo or carpaccio. I enjoyed the shrimp sauce, as it had a nice spicy tang. The vegetables livened up the dish and provided a much needed crunch. Spam Tortellini [$17]: This was probably the dish that I was least impressed with. It was still very good but just not as great as the others. The tortellini, which seems like it was made in-house, was cooked just right. The spam inside was very mild, you could probably mistake it for any meat in the world. I was disappointed that the poached egg did not run when it was broken into, that probably would have been the highlight of the meal. Dessert: Bruleed Hawaiian Pineapple [$10]: Dessert took a while to arrive, which was noticed by the kitchen, as they sent out a complimentary pineapple. I'm really glad I didn't order it on my own. It's really just caramelized pineapple. Bread Pudding [$8]: I definitely enjoyed the bread pudding as it was made with King's Hawaiian Bread. It was sweet but not cloyingly so. You couldn't tell that the ice cream served was pineapple, it was delicate. __The bill came to $53 which isn't terribly expensive but the kitchen has a few kinks to work out before I come back.

I saw something about some per se/jungshik alums venturing on this Korean/ Hawaiian/ Portuguese culinary adventure and as a bit of a skeptic about asian fusion, I was curious.After last night's exquisite meal, I will surely  recommend this to others who miss the big Island and enjoy some depth and that little kick to their food :)We were so excited to try the corned beef tongue musubi and oh my lord...I could eat 10 of these in one sitting! After washing down the musubi with some local beer, my friend and I went to work on the heart of palm/beet salad with crispy shallots and smoked tofu.  The tofu was interesting but wish it was a bit smokier or maybe even a little spicy?  Regardless, the dish was enjoyed and it was a nice palate starter. We moved on to the kampachi and soppressata, eggplant relish, and basil and as the kampachi was served sashimi style- it was almost too pretty to eat! So yummy and I can't stop thinking about how weird but well the dish came together.We then opted for the mochi crusted fluke which was a bit salty but nice chewy exterior layer and the braised honey comb tripe with rice cake and bamboo shoots which my friend and I were left yearning for that spicy kick we'd imagine from a dish resembling dduk bokki, it was still good! We ended the meal with a  Brûléed pineapple dessert and wow, I don't like desssert but this I could eat all day. It was the perfect finish with the lime zest and salt...yum.While their wine selection was great, I wish they had a cocktail list as it would be fun to see what they can stir up while paying homage to the 3 very distinct countries. The ambiance and service is great. It's nice to see well thought out refined food without the frou frou of a dinner jacket! I will surely be back to try everything else :)

I found a little gem tucked away near the St Mark's area. Noreetuh did nothing less than impress with their appetizers (round of applause to those yummy taro chips), those little pork potato buns that I can't recall the name of, ugh and their big eye tuna poke...so delicious. I've never tried poke before and I'm glad this was my first try. The seasoning was really nice, light, crisp with a hint of sesame oil...plus the seaweed made the whole dish come together. I ordered the flat iron steak with miso sauce and that was mouth watering. I loved the side of green beans and bean sprouts as it gave the dish a source of light and fresh tastes in between the miso sauce and steak bites. The meat was cooked to perfection. Finally for dessert, we went a little overboard with three dishes which included the Mochi waffles with whipped peanut butter, pineapple brûlée, and the Hawaiin bread pudding. The latter two were my favorite. The pineapple was deelicious! The atmosphere of the restaurant is really nice; intimate, cozy, and you'd be surprised with the extra space they have on the side and in the back. This would be the perfect place for a date night. It's nice to finally have a little taste of Hawaii in NYC. I'll definitely be coming back here again! :)

Damn. That was a wonderful meal. The entire staff is from Per Se and Jungsik and does it ever show. Incredible service. Incredible food. Get your reservation now because they will be booked solid almost immediately and for good reason.
Yummy in my tummy!  Add Noreetuh to the top your must try list.  The food exquisite.  The service impeccable.  Can't wait to eat here next week!

All right, so I had an amazing experience. The food is very fine, original, and flavorish. The service is very professional without being uptight, and the price is more than fair.We shared everything since we couldn't make up our minds. As apetizers, we had the crispy mushrooms, the pork croquettes, the tuna sahimis and the yellowtail kind of sahsimis. All delicious. As main, the pork belly and garlic shrimps won it. For desserts, we had the waffles, the hawaien pineapple and the pudding: OMG! I really recommend this place, great food, friendly staff and cozy atmosphere - and i am a super picky-on-food French girl ;)
